questions.text: 45 year old alcoholic patient presented with one week H/O diarrhoea, fever, nausea and right upper abdominal pain. USG revealed a 75 cc liver abscess. Stool examination shown below. Which of the following statement is false about this condition?
questions.solution:

Associate with golf hole shaped ulcers in ileocecal area.

questions.text: A child born in a known family of MEN syndrome is RET positive and is diagnosed as MEN 2 a. Prophylactic thyroidectomy should be performed in this patient at?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Within 5 years.

In MEN 2A (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A), patients have a germline mutation in the RET proto-oncogene, predisposing them to medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism. Since MTC develops early in life, prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended in RET-positive children, but the timing depends on the type of RET mutation. For MEN 2A, the standard recommendation is before the age of 5 years, as MTC can develop in early childhood but usually not in infancy.

Other Options:

A. Within 1 year: This recommendation applies to MEN 2B, which is more aggressive, with MTC developing in infancy; hence thyroidectomy should be done within the first year of life.

C. At Puberty: Too late for MEN 2A, as MTC may already be established by then.

D. Before 25 years: Far too delayed; risk of advanced medullary thyroid carcinoma would be very high.

questions.text: Ideal treatment for staghorn calculus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Ideal treatment for < 2cm> 2cm stone ideal treatment is PCNL STRUVITE STONES (STAGHORN CALCULI) Synonyms: infection stones, triple phosphate stones. Women > men, perhaps because of their susceptibility for UT1. Tend to grow in alkaline urine and tend to fill whole of the PCS. Composed of magnesium, ammonium & phosphate (MAP) Pathogenesis: Two conditions must coexist for crystallization of struvite. 

Urine pH of 7.2 or above. Ammonia in the urine (produced from hydrolysis of urea by urease producing bacteria). Two urological conditions which contribute to the tendency to form struvite calculi: Foreign body in the urinary tract e.g. Foley's catheter. Neurogenic bladder Most of the stag horn calculi are silent and cause progressive destruction of renal parenchyma. 

RENAL CALCULI Peak incidence 20-40 years; Males 3 times affected. Infectious stones (UTI common in women). MC Calculi are calcium stones occurring in combination with either oxalates or phosphates. 4 most common types of stones - Calcium containing stones [calcium oxalate (MC), calcium phosphate, mixed] - 70%. o Infection stones (struvite) - 15-20% Uric acid stones - 5 -10% Cystine stones - 1-5

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman suffering from asthma was brought to the emergency department because of a sudden onset of left- side paralysis. Imaging studies confirmed the diagnosis of thromboembolic stroke, and the patient started a treatment that included a drug that acts by blocking platelet P2Y12 receptors. Which of the following drugs has this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that works by irreversibly inhibiting the platelet P2Y12 ADP receptor. This prevents ADP-mediated activation of the GPIIb/IIIa complex, thereby reducing platelet aggregation. It is particularly useful in the prevention of thromboembolic events like ischemic stroke, acute coronary syndromes, and post-stent thrombosis. In this patient with thromboembolic stroke, clopidogrel helps prevent further platelet aggregation and recurrent events.

Other Options:

A. Warfarin: An oral anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X). It does not act on platelets or the P2Y12 receptor.

B. Aminocaproic acid: An antifibrinolytic agent that inhibits plasminogen activation. It is used in bleeding disorders, not in preventing stroke.

C. Alteplase: A tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) used to dissolve clots in acute ischemic stroke, but its mechanism is fibrinolysis, not platelet inhibition.

choices.text: Oxidation of ferrous iron in hemoglobin to ferric iron
A decrease in serum methemoglobin levels

questions.text: An 18-year-old college student presents to the Emergency straight from chemistry lab where he ingested an unknown compound. He complains of a headache, and is flushed, tachypneic and tachycardic. Suspecting cyanide poisoning, you administer amyl nitrite which causes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amyl nitrite converts the ferrous (Fe²⁺) iron in hemoglobin to ferric (Fe³⁺) iron, producing methemoglobin. Methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) has a high affinity for cyanide and so sequesters cyanide away from mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase (complex IV). By binding cyanide, methemoglobin prevents cyanide from inhibiting cellular respiration, thereby partially reversing the toxic block of oxidative phosphorylation. This is the basis for using nitrites (amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite) as part of an antidotal methemoglobin–forming kit in acute cyanide poisoning (used carefully because methemoglobinemia itself impairs O₂ delivery).

questions.text: Concentration of DNA is measured by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Absorption at 260 nm SsDNA has maximum absorption at 260 nm

The concentration of DNA is routinely measured using UV spectrophotometry. DNA and RNA absorb ultraviolet light strongly at 260 nm due to the presence of aromatic nitrogenous bases (adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine, uracil). The absorbance at 260 nm (A₂₆₀) is directly proportional to nucleic acid concentration. A standard conversion is used:
• An absorbance of 1 at 260 nm corresponds to ~50 µg/mL of double-stranded DNA.
Thus, A₂₆₀ measurement is the gold standard for quantifying DNA.

questions.text: PFK 1 inhibitor-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Citrate PFK1 is a regulated step in glycolysis that is bound to inhibitors
and activators. High levels of ATP allosterically inhibit PFK1, but AMP reverses the inhibitory action of
ATP. Therefore, the activity of the enzyme increases when the cellular ATP/AMP ratio is lowered.
Citrate is also an allosteric inhibitor for PFK1.

questions.text: Schedule X drugs are all except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Schedule X drugs in India are those with a high potential for abuse and dependence, requiring special prescription rules and storage. They include narcotics, psychotropics, and barbiturates like morphine, amphetamines, and phenobarbital, but thalidomide is not included in Schedule X. Thalidomide is instead regulated separately due to its teratogenic effects, and is distributed under strict guidelines, but it is not classified as a Schedule X drug.

Other Options:

A. Morphine: A strong opioid analgesic, classified under Schedule X due to high abuse potential.

C. Phenobarbital: A barbiturate, also included in Schedule X because of risk of dependence and misuse.

D. Amphetamine: A stimulant, classified under Schedule X for its abuse potential.

choices.text: Cholecystectomy with resection of the extrahepatic biliary tract and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. Subsequent “MRCP” reveals a cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film shown here. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

This is type I choledochal cyst which is the commonest type (>85%) Five major types are (Todani): 

• Type I cysts are the most common and represent 80-90% of choledochal cysts. They consist of saccular or fusiform dilatations of the common bile duct, which involve either a segment of the duct or the entire duct. 

• Type II choledochal cysts appear as an isolated diverticulum protruding from the wall of the common bile duct. 

• Type III choledochal cysts arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct (choledochocele). The surgical
management for each choledochal cyst type is described as follows: 

• Type I: Complete excision of cyst followed by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. 

• Type II: Complete excision of the dilated diverticulum comprising a type II choledochal cyst; the resultant defect in the common bile duct is
closed over a T-tube 

• Type III (choledochocele): choledochoceles measuring 3 cm or less can be treated effectively with endoscopic sphincterotomy, whereas lesions larger than 3 cm are excised surgically via a transduodenal approach. 

• Type IV: Complete excision of the dilated extrahepatic duct, followed by a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy to restore continuity. 

• Type V (Caroli disease): Hepatic lobectomy for disease limited to one hepatic lobe (left lobe usually affected); patients with bilobar disease manifesting signs of liver failure, biliary cirrhosis, or portal hypertension may require liver transplantation 

• Lilly technique: When the cyst adheres densely to the portal vein secondary to long-standing inflammatory reaction, it may not be possible to perform a complete, full-thickness excision of the cyst; the Lilly technique allows the serosal surface of the duct to be left adhering to
the portal vein, while the mucosa of the cyst wall is obliterated by curettage or cautery—theoretically, this removes the risk of malignant transformation in that segment of the duct

choices.text: Iron deficiency anaemia and RIF Mass

questions.text: Feature of Carcinoma of right colon is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Carcinoma of the right colon (cecum and ascending colon) typically grows as an exophytic, polypoidal mass. Because the lumen of the right colon is wide and the contents are liquid, obstruction is uncommon. Instead, the tumor often causes chronic occult blood loss, leading to iron deficiency anemia. On examination, a palpable right iliac fossa (RIF) mass may be found due to the bulky lesion.

Other Options:

B. Alternate constipation and diarrhea: More characteristic of left-sided colonic carcinoma, where the lumen is narrow, leading to partial obstruction and altered bowel habits.

C. Chronic obstruction: Again, more common in left colon cancers (especially sigmoid), since the feces are solid and lumen narrower.

D. Bleeding P/R: While bleeding can occur in any colonic carcinoma, fresh rectal bleeding is more typical of rectal or left-sided lesions, not right colon.

questions.text:
A young male was brough to emergency with RTA, injury to spine and paralysis. After triage ABC and intubation the patient was found to have weak pulsed without any external or internal bleeding sign. Heart rate of 50/min and systolic blood pressure of 88mmHg and temp 35degree C was
recorded. Most likely level of spinal injury for this patient is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) C 5

The patient has a history of road traffic accident (RTA) with spinal injury and paralysis. On examination, he has bradycardia (HR 50/min), hypotension (SBP 88 mmHg), weak pulses, and hypothermia (35°C). These findings are typical of neurogenic shock, which occurs due to disruption of sympathetic outflow from the spinal cord.
• The sympathetic nervous system arises from T1–L2 spinal levels.
• If the lesion is above T1 (high cervical or upper thoracic), sympathetic outflow is lost → unopposed vagal (parasympathetic) activity.
• This results in bradycardia, hypotension, warm/dry skin or hypothermia.
• Injury at C5 level can damage descending sympathetic fibers and cause neurogenic shock.

questions.text: A patient of pancreatic carcinoma (clinical case was given). You gave morphine for relieving pain. After few days, the pain is not relieved as relieved earlier. Why?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Desensitization of opioid receptor Explanation: 

• Tolerance occurs with chronic opioid use o Due to receptor desensitization or downregulation 

• Not due to upregulation or decreased absorption • Management: opioid rotation or adjuvants

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is being treated with raloxifene for osteoporosis. There is an increased risk of her developing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used for osteoporosis. Like estrogen, it carries an increased risk of venous thromboembolism, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). It does not increase the risk of uterine cancer and can actually reduce the risk of invasive breast cancer.

choices.text: A combination of an estrogen and progestin

questions.text: A 24-year-old married woman has failed to become pregnant after 2 years of unprotected intercourse. Which of the following would be effective in treating infertility due to anovulatory cycles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as an anti-estrogen in the hypothalamus, thereby blocking
negative feedback and increasing the pulsatile release of GnRH. This leads to increased FSH and LH secretion, stimulating follicular development and ovulation, making it effective for anovulatory infertility.

questions.text: A 25 year old man gets burnt when a stove bursts. His burns involve his hair , face , neck, chest on both sides and both arms (Sparing the forearms). what is the body surface area burnt?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Burn surface area is estimated by the Rule of Nines in adults. According to this rule:
• Head and neck = 9 percentage 
• Each upper limb = 9 percentage (arm 4.5 percentage front + 4.5 percentage back)
• Each lower limb = 18 percentage 
• Front of trunk = 18 percentage, back of trunk = 18 percentage 

In this case:
• Head and neck = 9percentage 
• Anterior chest (both sides) = 18percentage 
• Both arms, but sparing forearms → only upper arms involved (4.5 percentage each × 2 = 9 percentage)

Adding them: 9 + 18 + 9 = 36 percentage total body surface area burned.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient comes to OPD with lipodystrophy. On taking drug history, he told that he is taking drugs for his HIV infection and drugs are zidovudine, lamivudine and lopinavir/Ritonavir. Which of the following drug is used in the treatment of his lipodystrophy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Tesamorelin is a growth hormone-releasing factor analog approved specifically for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, particularly to reduce excess abdominal fat in patients on antiretroviral therapy.

questions.text: A patient with atrial fibrillation and CHF was started on a drug which acts by vagomimmetic action and by blocking Na K ATPase pump. What is the drug used for the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used in atrial fibrillation and CHF. It exerts a positive inotropic effect by inhibiting the Na+/K+-ATPase pump in
myocardial cells, and it has vagomimetic (parasympathomimetic) effects that slow AV nodal conduction, beneficial in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A patient is on treatment of acute migraine attack. Now he developed numbness & tingling at the tip of fingers. Which drug is responsible for this and drug used for treatment of this condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Ergotamine and Sodium nitroprusside Explanation:  • Ergotamine: vasoconstrictor → can cause digital ischemia o Tingling, numbness = vasospasm • Sodium nitroprusside: vasodilator → used to reverse this • Sumatriptan can cause similar effects but less
severe • Propranolol not used in acute attacks

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is being treated for diabetic coma in the intensive care unit. The patient has been receiving total parenteral feeding for the past three days. Today on morning rounds, the provider notices that he is less responsive than usual and suspects refeeding syndrome. Lab results
will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Refeeding syndrome • Hypophosphatemia is considered a hallmark of refeeding syndrome (RS) and is used as a surrogate marker. • Other electrolyte irregularities may also include but are not limited to decreased amounts of magnesium, potassium, and thiamine. • Hypoalbuminemia, hyponatremia, and hypocalcemia are not associated with RS. • With rising glucose levels, the body produces a countermeasure of insulin levels, which drives phosphorus and potassium intracellularly, causing a decrease in the amount of available extracellular potassium or hypokalemia.

questions.text: What is the substrate for the physiologically irreversible reaction in the Kreb’S & Citric acid cycle-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

In the Krebs (TCA) cycle, one of the physiologically irreversible reactions is the oxidative decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA, catalyzed by the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex. This step is highly exergonic and tightly regulated, making it physiologically irreversible. It also generates NADH and CO₂, linking energy production with cellular respiration.

Other Options:

A. Citrate: Formed from acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate via citrate synthase. While this reaction is irreversible, citrate itself is not the substrate for the physiologically most significant irreversible step in regulation.

C. Succinate: Oxidized to fumarate by succinate dehydrogenase. This is a reversible reaction, as FADH₂ can shuttle electrons bidirectionally depending on conditions.

D. Malate: Converted to oxaloacetate by malate dehydrogenase, which is near-equilibrium and reversible.

questions.text: Compound that joins glycolysis with glycogenesis & glycogenolysis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Glucose-6-phosphate is a central metabolic intermediate that connects glycolysis, glycogen synthesis (glycogenesis), and glycogen breakdown (glycogenolysis).

From glycolysis, glucose is phosphorylated to G6P by hexokinase/glucokinase.

In glycogenesis, G6P is converted to glucose-1-phosphate, then to UDP-glucose, which is used for glycogen synthesis.

In glycogenolysis, glycogen breakdown produces glucose-1-phosphate, which is converted back to G6P for entry into glycolysis or for release as free glucose in the liver (via glucose-6-phosphatase).

Other Options:

A. Glucose-1,6-bisphosphate: This is mainly an intermediate in glycolysis regulation and does not directly connect glycogen metabolism with glycolysis.

B. Glucose-1-phosphate: Important in glycogen metabolism (intermediate in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis), but it does not directly link to glycolysis until it is converted to G6P.

D. Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate: A committed step intermediate of glycolysis, but it has no direct role in glycogen metabolism.

questions.text: In Hybrid RNA-DNA, DNA is 5 CTTAAG 3 The sequence of RNA will be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

5CUUAAG3 Will be complimentary and read from 5 to 3 

When RNA hybridizes with DNA, it base pairs with complementary DNA strand.

·  DNA: 5′ CTTAAG 3′

·  Complementary strand (normally DNA) would be: 3′ GAATTC 5′

·  If RNA is made instead, it pairs similarly but replaces T with U.

Thus the RNA strand will be:

· 3′ GAAUUC 5′ → when written in 5′ → 3′ direction, it becomes 5′ CUUAAG 3′

questions.text: A 45-year-old male brought to casualty with severe headache. The neurologist attends that patient and orders for investigations. After examination and investigation doctor decides that the pain is due to increased intracranial pressure. Which of the following diuretic is most useful in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

• Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to rapidly reduce raised intracranial pressure. • Draws water out of brain tissue → reduces cerebral edema. • Other diuretics (acetazolamide, furosemide, HCTZ) have slower or different actions.

questions.text: A 58 year old male patient had BMI of 35. His physician started him on a drug for managing obesity. The drug lowers glucose and given via Parentral route. Identify the drug
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that is administered parenterally (subcutaneously). It is approved for both type 2 diabetes management and weight management (at higher doses for obesity) and works by slowing gastric emptying, increasing satiety, and promoting glucose-dependent insulin release.

questions.text: Anderson Hynes pyeloplasty is done for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anderson-Hynes pyeloplasty is the standard surgical treatment for PUJ obstruction, where there is a narrowing at the junction of the renal pelvis and proximal ureter. The procedure involves excision of the narrowed segment and creation of a tension-free, wide, spatulated ureteropelvic anastomosis, restoring free urine flow from the kidney to the ureter. It has a very high success rate and remains the gold standard for PUJ obstruction, especially in children.

questions.text: A psychotic patient, 3 days after taking haloperidol, presented with acute dystonia of muscles of neck. Best drug for managing this condition is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect (EPS) caused by typical antipsychotics like haloperidol, usually within hours to days of starting therapy. It manifests as painful, sustained muscle contractions (e.g., torticollis, oculogyric crisis).

The underlying mechanism is dopamine (D₂) blockade → cholinergic overactivity in the nigrostriatal pathway.

Treatment requires anticholinergic drugs such as Benzhexol (Trihexyphenidyl) or Benzatropine, which quickly relieve symptoms.

Incorrect responses:

B. Amantadine: A dopaminergic drug sometimes used in Parkinsonism or tardive dyskinesia, but not first-line for acute dystonia.

C. Selegiline: A MAO-B inhibitor used in Parkinson’s disease; not effective in drug-induced acute dystonia.

D. Entacapone: A COMT inhibitor, used with levodopa in Parkinson’s disease; no role in managing acute EPS.

questions.text: Shamlin classification is used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Carotid body tumour

choices.text: Bigger size prostate can be removed
Saline can be used reducing the risk of dilutional hyponatremia

questions.text: Advantage of Bipolar cautery over monopolar cautery for TURP is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Saline can be used reducing the risk of dilutional hyponatremia. In Bipolar cautery TURP (Transurethral Resection of Prostate), normal saline can be used as the irrigation fluid because the current is confined between the two electrodes of the bipolar loop, preventing current dispersion through the patient’s body. This eliminates the need for non-conductive solutions (e.g., glycine, sorbitol) used in monopolar cautery, which carry the risk of TURP syndrome (dilutional hyponatremia, fluid overload, CNS toxicity). Thus, bipolar TURP significantly reduces the risk of this complication.

Other Options:

A. Bigger size prostate can be removed: Not a specific advantage of bipolar cautery. Prostate size management depends more on surgical technique than on type of cautery.

B. Less operative time: Operative time is generally similar in both monopolar and bipolar TURP; choice of cautery doesn’t significantly shorten surgery.

C. Less bleeding: Both monopolar and bipolar achieve good hemostasis; bleeding reduction is not the primary distinguishing factor.

questions.text: Lipoprotein with scavenging action is OR Concentration of which is inversely related to the risk of coronary heart disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 
HDL More is HDL less risk of CAD .

High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) is known as the “good cholesterol.” Its major protective role is reverse cholesterol transport — it scavenges excess cholesterol from peripheral tissues (including arterial walls) and delivers it back to the liver for metabolism and excretion in bile. This action reduces atherosclerotic plaque formation.
Thus, HDL concentration is inversely related to the risk of coronary heart disease (CHD): higher HDL = lower risk.
Other options:
• B. LDL 
Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL) is the major carrier of cholesterol to peripheral tissues. High LDL levels are directly related to increased risk of CHD and atherosclerosis.
• C. VLDL 
Very Low-Density Lipoprotein (VLDL) mainly transports triglycerides from liver to tissues. Increased VLDL also contributes to atherogenesis, but it is not protective.
• D. None 
Since HDL clearly has scavenging action and protective inverse correlation with CHD risk, the correct answer is not “None.”

Pain is the most common presentation.
Spontaneous bleeding is called Wunderlich syndrome
Beckwith wiedeman syndrome is a risk factor

questions.text: False statement about Renal angiomyolipoma is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Treatment of < 4 cm asymptomatic tumour is observation and <4 cm
symptomatic tumour is Angio-embolization. Pain and haematuria are two main presenting symptom It
is associated with Tuberous sclerosis not Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient was given drug X, as he had pain in facial nerve distribution area while chewing and talking. He now presents with Dilutional Hyponatremia and Hepatotoxicity. Which is the drug X patient is taking
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant and neuropathic pain drug commonly used in trigeminal neuralgia (facial nerve distribution pain). It is associated with side effects such as dilutional hyponatremia (due to syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion – SIADH) and hepatotoxicity. These features match the clinical presentation described in the question.

Other Options:

A. Phenytoin: Used as an anticonvulsant; can cause gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, megaloblastic anemia, ataxia, and teratogenicity, but not dilutional hyponatremia.

B. Sodium valproate: Can cause hepatotoxicity and pancreatitis, but not typically SIADH or hyponatremia.

D. Ethosuximide: Drug of choice for absence seizures; adverse effects include GI upset, fatigue, headache, urticaria, but not hyponatremia or hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following does not form a boundary of triangle of Doom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The Triangle of Doom is an anatomical triangle defined by the vas deferens medially, spermatic vessels laterally and peritoneal folds covering external iliac vessels inferiorly. This triangle contains external iliac artery and vessels, the deep circumflex iliac vein, the genital branch of genitofemoral nerve and hidden by fascia the femoral nerve.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male Patient presented with chest pain and was given nitroglycerine sublingual
and pain got relieved. The drug acts by following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) • Releasing NO • Explanation: Nitroglycerin is metabolized to nitric
oxide (NO), which then activates guanylyl cyclase, leading to increased cGMP and relaxation of
vascular smooth muscle, especially in veins (venodilation) and coronary arteries. This reduces
preload and improves blood flow to the myocardium, relieving angina.

questions.text: A 40-year male patient was on chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma. His total leucocytes count is now 2000cells/mm3. Which of the following drug is effective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Filgrastim • Explanation: Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating
factor (G-CSF) that stimulates the production and release of neutrophils from the bone marrow. It is
used to prevent or treat neutropenia (low leukocyte count, specifically neutrophils) caused by
chemotherapy, thus reducing the risk of infection.

questions.text: Melanin is derived from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Tyrosine

Explanation (correct response):
Melanin, the pigment responsible for skin, hair, and eye color, is synthesized in melanocytes from the amino acid tyrosine. The key enzyme is tyrosinase, which converts tyrosine → DOPA → dopaquinone, which then polymerizes to form melanin (eumelanin or pheomelanin).
Thus, melanin is a derivative of tyrosine.
Other options:
• B. Tryptophan 
• Precursor of serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (vitamin B3), but not melanin.
• C. Methionine 
Sulfur-containing amino acid, precursor of SAM (S-adenosyl methionine) used in methylation reactions, but not melanin.
• D. Cysteine 
Contributes sulfur groups in the synthesis of pheomelanin (red/yellow pigment), but the fundamental precursor of melanin remains tyrosine.

choices.text: Local topical cauterization with trichloroacetic acetic acid

questions.text: A chronic tobacco chewer for 30 years presented with swelling of left cheek on examination a white membrane was seen over gingival mucosal fold what will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Surgical excision and BX

Leukoplakia is a clinical term for a white patch or plaque on the oral mucosa that cannot be scraped off and cannot be characterized as any other disease, like candidiasis. Given the patient's history of chronic tobacco use, this lesion is highly suspicious for a precancerous condition and carries a risk of malignant transformation.
A biopsy (BX) is the most critical next step to establish a definitive diagnosis and determine the presence of dysplasia (abnormal cell growth) or frank malignancy. Depending on the biopsy results, surgical excision is often the primary treatment for these lesions to prevent them from becoming cancerous.

questions.text: 5 Fluorouracil is converted to its active form after administration of a drug that further leads to destruction of cells. Which of the following type of inhibition best describes this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Competitive inhibition
•  5-FU as a prodrug:
• 5-FU is converted inside cells to FdUMP, which resembles the natural substrate dUMP (deoxyuridine monophosphate).
•  Enzyme target:
• FdUMP inhibits thymidylate synthase (TS), the enzyme responsible for converting dUMP → dTMP, a critical step in DNA synthesis.
•  Mechanism described as competitive:
• FdUMP competes with the natural substrate dUMP for binding at the active site of thymidylate synthase.
• By occupying the active site, it prevents dUMP from binding, thus blocking DNA synthesis and leading to cell death.

questions.text: A 35-Year-old female presented with burning micturition and symptoms of UTI. Which fluroquinolones is least likely to be effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
Moxifloxacin • Explanation: Moxifloxacin has excellent activity against respiratory pathogens and is generally not recommended for urinary tract infections (UTIs) because its urinary concentrations are lower compared to other fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin. It's metabolized more extensively by the liver, leading to less active drug being excreted in the urine.

choices.text: Ryles tube + TPN for 7 days following which if unresolved take for exploratory laparotomy
Ryles tube + TPN for 14 days following which if unresolved take for exploratory laparotomy

questions.text: A young 24 years old male met with a RTA following with his motor bike handle impacted over the abdomen following which he was taken to emergency where a CT revealed duodenal hematoma obstructing the entire lumen, what is the next step in management ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The approach to management of duodenal injuries depends on the location of the injury and the amount of tissue destruction. Hematomas of the duodenal wall will often resolve without intervention and are an issue only if they cause a gastric outlet obstruction. Treatment of obstructing hematomas consists of gastric decompression, initiation of total parenteral nutrition, and reevaluation of gastric emptying with a contrast study after 5 to 7 days. If the duodenal obstruction persists after approximately 14 days, operative exploration is warranted to evacuate hematoma, evaluate for perforation, stricture, or associated pancreatic injury. Hematomas will frequently decompress spontaneously during mobilization of the duodenum and the intestinal wall should then be evaluated for injury. Duodenal hematomas identified incidentally during laparotomy should not be intentionally opened unless there is a concern for full-thickness injury.

questions.text: The drug to be taken only on prescription by registered medical practitioner comes under which schedule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•  Schedule G:
• Drugs that carry mandatory cautionary labels like “Caution: Not to be sold without medical advice.”
• Mostly over-the-counter (OTC) drugs with some restrictions.
• Not strictly prescription-only.
•  Schedule H: 
Drugs that are prescription-only.
• Cannot be sold without a valid prescription from a registered medical practitioner.
• Must have the label: “To be sold by retail on the prescription of a Registered Medical Practitioner only.”
•  Schedule X:
• Drugs that are highly addictive or habit-forming (e.g., certain sedatives).
• Prescription-only with stricter storage and record-keeping.
•  Schedule Y:
• Deals with clinical trial requirements in India.

questions.text: Which of the following medications would be preferred as monotherapy for the treatment of a 53-year-old man with moderate hypertension and mild benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Terazosin is an α1-adrenergic blocker that is effective in treating both hypertension and lower urinary tract symptoms of BPH. In a patient with moderate hypertension and mild BPH, terazosin helps relax prostatic smooth muscle improving urinary flow, while also lowering blood pressure. This makes it an ideal choice for monotherapy in such cases.

Other Options:

A. Carvedilol: A non-selective β-blocker with α1-blocking activity, primarily used for hypertension and heart failure, but does not specifically improve BPH symptoms.

B. Propranolol: A non-selective β-blocker, used for hypertension, arrhythmias, and migraines, but no benefit for BPH, and may worsen urinary symptoms.

C. Tamsulosin: A selective α1A-blocker, primarily used for BPH symptoms, but has minimal effect on systemic blood pressure, making it less suitable as monotherapy for hypertension.

questions.text: A female patient was on warfarin therapy for prosthetic valves. What advice should be given to her regarding use of this drug during early pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Change to heparin Explanation: • Warfarin is teratogenic, especially
during 6–12 weeks gestation (organogenesis). • It causes fetal warfarin syndrome (nasal hypoplasia,
stippled epiphyses). • Heparin is safer in pregnancy as it does not cross placenta.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of absorbable suture
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Poliglecaprone (Monocryl) is a synthetic absorbable monofilament suture. It undergoes hydrolytic degradation in tissue and is absorbed completely, usually within 90–120 days.

Incorrect Options:

A. Polyamide (Nylon) – This is a synthetic non-absorbable monofilament suture. It is strong, has minimal tissue reactivity, and is commonly used in skin closure.

B. Polyester – Another synthetic non-absorbable braided suture. It has excellent tensile strength and is used in cardiovascular, ophthalmic, and orthopedic procedures.

C. Polybutester – A synthetic non-absorbable monofilament suture. It is highly elastic and is often used in dynamic tissues like vessels and skin, allowing for stretching without breaking.

questions.text: Commonest melanoma seen in elderly people on the face is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Superficial spreading melanoma: Most common type (65-70%). Most
common on the trunk in men and women and on the legs in women Nodular melanoma: About 25%
are of this type. It is also found in parts of the body only exposed to the sun. So it is most often found
on the chest or back. Nodular melanomas are often very dark brownish black or black in colour. The
depth of the lesion appears to correlate with the prognosis of the patient, and nodular melanoma is
less often amenable to definitive treatment than is the superficial spreading variety. Lentigo maligna
melanoma: 10% are this type. Lentigo MM is most common in elderly people and commonest on the
face. This type of melanoma grows very slowly. Acral lentiginous melanoma: This type is most
commonly found on the palms and soles or around the big toenail. It can also grow under the nails.

questions.text: Which among the following is not seen in fasting hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Glucagon excess Glucagon excess contributes to hyperglycaemia whereas reduced glucagon response to insulin-induced hypoglycaemia promotes severe hypoglycaemia. It is expected that drugs that are able to reduce glucagon secretion in concert with strategies directed to recover glucagon secretion to hypoglycaemia might contribute to improve the overall glycaemic control in diabetes.

questions.text: Morphine and pentazocine both act upon similar receptors in the central nervous system and produce analgesic effect. If pentazocine is given to a morphine addict it may produce withdrawal symptoms. What kind of action does pentazocine have at opioid mu receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Pentazocine is a mixed opioid agonist-antagonist: it acts as a kappa (κ) receptor agonist producing analgesia, but at mu (μ) receptors, it acts as a full antagonist. In a morphine-dependent patient, pentazocine can displace morphine from μ receptors, leading to precipitation of withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, sweating, and tachycardia. This occurs because it blocks the receptor while providing no full μ receptor-mediated effect.

Other Options:

B. A partial agonist action: Partial agonists (e.g., buprenorphine at μ receptors) activate the receptor partially, producing some analgesia with lower risk of respiratory depression; pentazocine is not a partial agonist at μ.

C. A full agonist action: Full agonists (e.g., morphine, fentanyl) fully activate μ receptors to produce maximal analgesia and euphoria; pentazocine does not produce full μ receptor effects.

D. An inverse agonist action: Inverse agonists (theoretical concept in some receptor systems) produce effects opposite to agonist stimulation; pentazocine is not an inverse agonist at μ receptors.

questions.text: Levodopa and carbidopa combination doesn't reduce which of the following side effect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Psychosis 

• Explanation: 

The combination of levodopa and carbidopa (Sinemet) significantly reduces peripheral side effects of levodopa like severe vomiting and arrhythmias by inhibiting its peripheral metabolism. However, central nervous system side effects such as psychosis (hallucinations, delusions) are due to increased dopamine activity in the brain and are often not reduced, and can even be exacerbated, by levodopa. Hypertension is not a common side effect of this combination.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient presents with mild pain in left lower abdomen, constipation, feeling of incomplete defecation and mucous diarrhoea off and on. There is mild tenderness in left iliac fossa. Colonoscopic and Barium enema picture is given below. What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Colonic Diverticulitis
• Common in old age
• West > India (high fiber is protective)
• Involves only colon, Sigmoid is most common site.
• Presents with bleeding or diverticulitis
• Most common vessel to bleed in diverticulosis- Branches of SMA
• Hinchey classification is used for diverticulitis
• Diverticulosis
First Investigation is Coloscopy. IOC is Ba enema (Saw tooth appearance).
Diverticulitis – IOC is CECT

questions.text: In video assisted thoracoscopic surgery for better vision the space in the operative field is created by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• In contrast to laparoscopic surgeries, working space for VATS (video assisted thoracoscopic surgery) is not created by insufflations of gases, rather air is removed from ipsilateral lung so as to collapse the lung. For VATS one lung anaesthesia is used.

• VATS requires most patients to be in a lateral decubitus position.

• VATS is performed under general anaesthesia, usually with One Lung Ventilation (Usually with double lung tube).

• Minute ventilation is ideally maintained with lower tidal volumes (5-7 ml/kg) and higher respiratory rates with a peak inflation pressure of less than 35 cm H2O.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in patients with metastatic HER 2 neu positive breast cancer which is resistant to Trastuzumab.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Lapatinib is used for treatment for solid tumours such as breast and lung cancer. It is used for patients with advanced metastatic breast cancer in conjunction with the chemotherapy drug capecitabine. Lapatinib is a human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2(HER2/ERBB2) and epidermal growth factor receptor (HER1/EGFR/ERBB1) tyrosine kinases inhibitor.

questions.text: A 2 year child presents with failure to thrive and repeated episides of fever. Abdominal examination shows a mass in the left flank. A biopsy from the mass is as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children and usually arises from the adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain. It often presents in children under 5 years with abdominal mass, systemic features (fever, failure to thrive), and sometimes metastases. The histopathology shows small round blue cells arranged in sheets along with Homer-Wright rosettes (tumor cells surrounding a central area filled with neuropil but no lumen), as seen in the provided image. These features strongly point to neuroblastoma.

Incorrect Options:

B. Nephroblastoma (Wilms’ tumor) – Another common childhood abdominal tumor, but histology shows a triphasic pattern (blastemal, stromal, epithelial elements). Clinically, Wilms’ tumor often presents as an asymptomatic abdominal mass, not usually with systemic illness like prolonged fever.

C. Multicystic dysplastic kidney – A congenital renal anomaly characterized by multiple cysts and disorganized renal tissue, not a malignant tumor. Histology does not show sheets of small round cells or rosettes.

D. Hepatoblastoma – The most common malignant liver tumor in children, usually associated with an abdominal mass and elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). Histology shows epithelial (fetal/embryonal) and sometimes mesenchymal elements, not small round blue cells or rosettes.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause a high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Methanol poisoning Explanation: High anion gap metabolic acidosis is
often caused by conditions that increase the production of organic acids, such as methanol poisoning,
diabetic ketoacidosis, and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Woman with cervical cancer stage 3b what is management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Chemo radiation Concurrent chemoradiation is the standard of care for
locally advanced cervical cancer, including Stage IIIB. This involves external beam radiation therapy
(EBRT) delivered concomitantly with chemotherapy, typically a platinum-based agent like cisplatin.
The chemotherapy acts as a radiosensitizer, enhancing the effectiveness of the radiation in killing
cancer cells. This combined approach has been shown to improve local control and overall survival
compared to radiation therapy alone for these advanced stages.

questions.text: Describe the hsg findings shown above
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Bilateral hydrosalpinx Hydrosalpinx refers to the accumulation of serous fluid within a fallopian tube, usually due to previous pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), endometriosis, or tubal surgery. In this HSG, both fallopian tubes appear dilated and tortuous, which is classic for hydrosalpinx. There may be no peritoneal spillage of contrast if the distal tubes are blocked, as seen here. The distended tubes take on a "retort" or "sausage-like" shape. This is the hallmark radiological feature that distinguishes hydrosalpinx from other pathologies.

questions.text: Which radiological investigation will not help in differentiating septate from bicornuate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Hysteroscopy 

Hysteroscopy allows direct visualization of the endometrial cavity but does not visualize the external contour of the uterus. This makes it inadequate for distinguishing between a septate and bicornuate uterus, as both anomalies can present with a divided endometrial cavity. The key distinction between these anomalies lies in the external fundal contour: flat or convex in septate uterus vs. concave (greater than 10 mm indentation) in bicornuate uterus. Since hysteroscopy cannot assess this, it cannot differentiate between the two anomalies reliably, making it the incorrect/inadequate modality for differentiation.

questions.text: Patient presents with constant leakage of urine and is diagnosed to have a genital fistula. Methylene blue swab test is done and the upper swab gets stained. Which of the following is the most likely type of fistula in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Vesicovaginal fistula In the methylene blue swab test for urinary
fistulas, methylene blue dye is instilled into the bladder. If the upper vaginal swab is stained with blue
dye, it indicates a connection between the bladder and the vagina, as the dye has leaked from the
bladder into the upper part of the vaginal vault. This specific finding is characteristic of a
vesicovaginal fistula. A ureterovaginal fistula would typically stain a swab placed higher, as it
involves the ureter. Urethrovaginal fistulas are lower and involve the urethra, while uterovesical
fistulas are between the uterus and bladder and would not cause vaginal leakage in this manner.

questions.text:
A 35 year healthy man had a snake bite, based on his description the doctor was confused between two most venomous snakes, following which he was administered polyvalent anti Snake Venom (ASV)and was discharged from the hospital after a week. Three days after discharge he
develops high grade fever, arthralgia, lymphadenopathy, facial swelling and erythema in hands and feet. Which of the following explains the manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Immune complex deposition. This is a classical presentation of serum sickness disease (SSD) which is type III HSR following antibody injection. The ASV will contain animal antibodies which will be recognised as non self by the patient and mounts an immune response, the antibodies form immune complexed and deposit in multiple locations leading to generalised disease. SSD can occur after injections anti thymocyte immunoglobulin and even after monoclonal antibodies

questions.text: The following are indications for assisted ventilation in acute severe asthma EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Decline in PaCO2 levels CONSENSUS INDICATORS FOR INTUBATION

Clinical Cardiac arrest 
Respiratory arrest 
Altered sensorium 
Progressive exhaustion 
Silent chest Severe hypoxemia with maximal oxygen delivery

questions.text: Which ABG result is most indicative of a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

pH 7.25, PaCO2 60 mmHg, HCO3- 18 mEq/L

The ABG results show acidemia (low pH) with both elevated PaCO2 (respiratory acidosis) and decreased HCO3-(metabolic acidosis), indicating a mixed disorder.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady with polydipsia and polyuria. Her symptoms started soon after a road traffic accident 6 months ago. The blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg with no postural drop. The daily urinary output is 6-8 liters investigation showed Na-130 meq/l,K-3.5 meq/l,urea-15 mg/dl,sugar-64 mg/dl. The plasma osmolality is 268 msosm/L and urine osmolality 45 osmol/L. The most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

This patient presents with polydipsia and polyuria with very high urine output (6–8 L/day). Laboratory data shows:

Hyponatremia (Na = 130 mEq/L)

Low plasma osmolality (268 mOsm/kg)

Very dilute urine (urine osmolality 45 mOsm/kg)

These findings suggest that the kidneys are functioning normally but are producing very dilute urine due to excessive water intake, consistent with psychogenic polydipsia. The history of road traffic accident may indicate a psychogenic trigger or behavioral component.

Other Options:

A. Central diabetes insipidus: Would present with hypernatremia, high plasma osmolality, and inappropriately dilute urine, because of deficient ADH secretion. Here, plasma sodium is low, which rules out central DI.

B. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus: Similar to central DI, would show hypernatremia with dilute urine, but kidneys are resistant to ADH. Again, low sodium here makes this unlikely.

C. Resolving acute tubular necrosis: Would show recovery of renal function but usually polyuria is accompanied by rising BUN/creatinine, not low urea as in this case.

questions.text: A 72 year old right handed man was admitted to the stroke unit.A CT brain scan performed identified an infarct in right middle cerebral artery territory .The following signs typically occur with non dominant cortical lesions :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Dressing apraxia. 

The dominant cerebral cortex is on the left in the majority of right handed people is specifically involved in reading math(dyscalculia),writing and language. Apraxia’s involving visuospatial tasks like dressing and drawing shapes is a symptom of dysfunction in the non dominant lobe .More subtle functions of the dominant parietal lobe include naming fingers (If abnormal this is called a finger agnosia ) and left to right discrimination.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is noted to have small pinpoint hemorrhages on the skin, appearing over the past 3 days. On examination the child's vital signs are normal. There are petechae over skin of extremities and trunk. A CBC shows Hgb 14.3 g/dL, Hct 43%, MCV 90 fL, platelet count 19,300/microliter, and WBC count 9370/microliter. This condition resolves over the next month without treatment. Which of the following is the most likely antecedent event for this child's illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This child presents with acute onset petechiae, severe thrombocytopenia (platelets 19,300/µL), normal hemoglobin and WBC counts, and the illness resolves spontaneously within a month. These features are classic for immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) in children. ITP is often preceded by a viral infection, most commonly upper respiratory tract infections such as RSV, influenza, or varicella, which trigger an autoimmune response leading to platelet destruction.

Other Options:

A. Sulfonamide ingestion: Certain drugs can cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia, but this is less common in children and usually occurs after exposure to the drug, which is not indicated here.

C. Aspirin ingestion: Aspirin can impair platelet function, but it does not reduce platelet count; thus, aspirin would not explain the severe thrombocytopenia.

D. History of trauma: Trauma can cause localized bruising or hematoma, but would not result in widespread petechiae or severe thrombocytopenia.

choices.text: Any level of radiation exposure is unsafe

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman underwent an X-ray examination. What radiation exposure level is considered safe during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

During pregnancy, the fetus is most sensitive to ionizing radiation, especially during the first trimester. Radiation exposure below 5 rads (0.05 Gy) is considered safe and not associated with fetal malformations, growth restriction, or miscarriage. Most diagnostic radiologic procedures, such as single X-rays of extremities or chest, deliver radiation well below this threshold.

Other Options:

A. Up to 10 rads (0.1 Gy): This exceeds the safe threshold, and repeated exposures above this may increase the risk of fetal anomalies, especially in early pregnancy.

C. Up to 15 rads (0.15 Gy): Far above the recommended limit; may significantly increase risk of developmental defects.

D. Any level of radiation exposure is unsafe: This is incorrect; low-level diagnostic radiation (<5 rads) is considered safe and often unavoidable for maternal care.

questions.text: A 38 year old lady presents with easy fatigue, peripheral blood examination shows Hb 8 g/dl, MCH 27, MCV 80 fl, RBC count 2.9 millions, retic count 0.5%. Which of the following is likely a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This patient presents with fatigue and laboratory findings of pancytopenia:

Hb = 8 g/dL (anemia)

RBC = 2.9 million/µL (low)

Reticulocyte count = 0.5% (low, indicating decreased bone marrow production)

The MCV is normal (80 fL), suggesting a normocytic anemia, and low reticulocyte count indicates hypoproliferative anemia. These features are consistent with aplastic anemia, a condition characterized by bone marrow failure, resulting in decreased production of RBCs, WBCs, and platelets.

Other Options:

A. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): Typically presents with hemolytic anemia, hemoglobinuria, and sometimes thrombosis. Reticulocyte count is usually elevated due to hemolysis.

B. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA): Presents with anemia, jaundice, elevated reticulocyte count, and positive Coombs test. Reticulocyte count here is low, which does not fit AIHA.

C. Iron deficiency anemia: Usually microcytic hypochromic anemia (MCV <80 fL, MCH low), sometimes with elevated RDW. Here, MCV is normal and reticulocyte count is low, making iron deficiency less likely.

questions.text: The given is the finding of the Pap smear of a 45 years old female with left ovarian tumor in her late menstrual phase showing squamous cells. What is the likely histology of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Granulosa cell tumor Granulosa cell tumors are a type of ovarian tumor
well-known for producing estrogen. This elevated estrogen level can lead to significant hormonal
effects on the female reproductive tract, including the cervix and vagina. Prolonged estrogen
stimulation can cause proliferation and maturation of the squamous epithelium in these areas. While
the atypical squamous cells seen in the Pap smear are not directly caused by estrogen (they are
typically associated with HPV infection or other irritants), the hyperestrogenic state created by a
granulosa cell tumor can lead to changes in the squamous cells of the lower genital tract, which
might be the indirect association the question is highlighting.

questions.text: 60 Y/M, Diabetic and chronic alcoholic was admitted to the hospital with a fever, cough with red currant jelly sputum. Physical examination is remarkable for a temperature of 39_C and the presence of bronchial breath sounds on the right side of the chest. Except for an elevated white count. Chest radiography reveals Right sided opacity. Which of the following organism can produce the below feature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

This patient presents with fever, productive cough with red currant jelly sputum, and right-sided lung opacity with bronchial breath sounds on chest X-ray. The classic chest radiograph feature for Klebsiella pneumoniae includes:

Lobar consolidation (often upper lobes, especially right)

Bulging fissures due to exudate

Cavitation in severe cases

Klebsiella pneumoniae is more common in alcoholics, diabetics, and debilitated patients, and produces the thick, mucoid, blood-tinged “currant jelly” sputum described in the case.

Other Options:

A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Usually causes nosocomial pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia, often with multilobar or patchy infiltrates rather than classic lobar consolidation.

B. E. coli: Can cause pneumonia in immunocompromised patients, but typically does not produce red currant jelly sputum or bulging fissure sign.

D. Staphylococcus aureus: Causes secondary pneumonia, often post-influenza, with patchy infiltrates, abscesses, or empyema, rather than classic lobar consolidation with red currant jelly sputum.

questions.text: Following are the findings in early stages of DM nephropathy EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

In the early stages of diabetic nephropathy, the kidneys typically enlarge due to hyperfiltration and increased renal blood flow. Shrinking of the kidneys is not an early feature; it occurs in advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) when there is significant nephron loss and scarring.

Other Options:

A. Micro-albuminuria: This is one of the earliest detectable signs of diabetic nephropathy. It indicates that the glomerular filtration barrier is becoming leaky, allowing small amounts of albumin to appear in urine.

B. Supranormal GFR: Early in diabetic nephropathy, there is hyperfiltration, leading to a supranormal or elevated GFR. This is due to glomerular hypertrophy and increased glomerular pressure.

D. Thickening of the GBM: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) occurs early and is a hallmark of structural changes in diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with progressive bilateral loss of central vision. You obtain a detailed family history from this patient and produce the associated pedigree. Which of the following transmission patterns is most consistent with this patient’s family history?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Looking at the pedigree:

Only females are affected in some generations, but both genders can be affected — check if transmission is strictly maternal.

Maternal inheritance pattern: All children of an affected mother are at risk, regardless of sex, but children of affected fathers are not affected.

In the pedigree, the affected mother passes the trait to all her children, consistent with mitochondrial inheritance.

Other Options:

A. Autosomal dominant: Would show vertical transmission through both sexes, and both males and females can transmit the trait. In this pedigree, the key feature is that only children of affected mothers are affected, not fathers.

B. X-linked recessive: Typically more males are affected, and the trait is transmitted through carrier females. Affected fathers do not pass it to sons. The pedigree does not match this pattern.

C. X-linked dominant: Both males and females can be affected, but affected fathers transmit to all daughters and no sons. This does not fully fit the pedigree pattern shown.

questions.text:
A 28 year old multi-gravid woman is having severe anemia and is currently at 38 weeks of gestation. The obstetrician decides to transfuse 3 units of blood over next 2 days. The blood bank did not have component separation facility thus they issued whole blood. She was transfused three units
of blood each 8 hrs apart. 1 hour into the third unit of transfusion the patient develops breathlessness. Pulse is 100 per minute, respiratory rate is 24/min, BP 135/85, temperature 98 F, oxygen saturation is at 90. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

TACO is a complication of blood transfusion caused by volume overload, especially in patients who receive rapid or large-volume transfusions, or those with underlying cardiac or renal compromise.

Clinical features typically appear within 1–6 hours of transfusion: dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypertension, and hypoxemia.

Pulmonary congestion may be evident on chest X-ray as bilateral infiltrates or cardiomegaly.

In this patient, transfusion of 3 units of whole blood in short intervals likely led to fluid overload, explaining her breathlessness, tachycardia, mild hypertension, and low oxygen saturation.

Other options:

A – Transfusion Associated GVHD (TA-GVHD):

TA-GVHD is caused by donor lymphocytes attacking the host, usually in immunocompromised patients.

Symptoms occur 4–30 days post-transfusion, including fever, rash, diarrhea, liver dysfunction, and pancytopenia.

This is unlikely here because the patient developed acute symptoms during the transfusion, not delayed manifestations.

C – Transfusion Associated Acute Lung Injury (TRALI):

TRALI is an acute non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to donor antibodies reacting with recipient leukocytes.

Onset is within 6 hours of transfusion, with hypoxemia, fever, hypotension, and pulmonary infiltrates.

Differentiating features: normal or low blood pressure, no fluid overload, and often fever.

In this case, the patient has hypertension and volume overload features, making TRALI less likely.

D – Transfusion Associated Anaphylaxis:

Severe allergic reaction to plasma proteins, with urticaria, hypotension, respiratory distress, or angioedema.

Usually occurs within minutes of starting transfusion.

This patient’s blood pressure is elevated, and there are no allergic features, making this unlikely.

questions.text: The vacutainer used for measuring ESR and it’s ratio of anticoagulant with blood is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) is measured using anticoagulated blood to prevent clotting.

The black-top vacutainer contains sodium citrate as the anticoagulant.

The anticoagulant to blood ratio is 1:4, meaning 1 part sodium citrate to 4 parts blood.

Proper ratio is essential because too much anticoagulant slows sedimentation, and too little may allow clotting, both affecting the ESR result.

Other options:

A – Black 1:9:

Incorrect ratio; 1:9 is typically used in coagulation studies with sodium citrate, not ESR.

B – Blue 1:9:

Light blue top vacutainers are also sodium citrate, usually 1:9 ratio, but used for coagulation tests like PT, aPTT, not ESR.

D – Blue 4:1:

Incorrect both in color and ratio; 4:1 ratio would mean too much blood relative to anticoagulant, which is not used for ESR.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man has complained of mild burning substernal pain following meals for the past 3 years. Upper GI endoscopy is performed and biopsies are taken of an erythematous area of the lower esophageal mucosa 3 cm above the gastroesophageal junction. There is no mass lesion, no
ulceration, and no hemorrhage noted. The biopsies show the presence of columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Which of the following mucosal alterations is most likely represented by these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Metaplasia is the substitution of one tissue normally found at a site for another. The esophageal stratified squamous epithelium undergoes metaplasia in response to the ongoing inflammation from reflux of gastric contents. This is common in the lower esophagus with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with Alport Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

COL4A5 Explanation: Alport Syndrome is most commonly associated with mutations in the COL4A5 gene, which encodes the alpha-5 chain of type IV collagen. This mutation leads to defects in the glomerular basement membrane, resulting in kidney disease, hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.

questions.text: All are disadvantages of using DMPA except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Increases Dysmenorrhea Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA), commonly known as the birth control shot, is known to have several side effects. These include a delayed return of fertility after discontinuation (A), a temporary decrease in bone mineral density (B), and most commonly, irregular bleeding patterns, which can eventually lead to amenorrhea (no
periods) for many users (C). However, DMPA is actually often prescribed to treat conditions like dysmenorrhea (painful periods) and menorrhagia (heavy periods) because it thins the uterine lining and can lead to a reduction or cessation of menstrual bleeding

questions.text: Regarding bacterial vaginosis true are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Positive clue cells in 100

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, typically seen in bacterial vaginosis (BV). While their presence is a diagnostic hallmark, they are not found in all cases. Studies show clue cells are present in the majority but not 100% of patients, making the statement incorrect. This is why C is the correct answer to the “NOT true” question.

Incorrect Options:

A. Vaginal discharge with pH 5–6:
In BV, the vaginal pH rises above normal (normal ≤4.5) due to loss of lactobacilli and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria. A pH of 5–6 is typical, so this statement is true.

B. Fishy odor with KOH:
The characteristic “fishy” odor appears when 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to vaginal discharge (Whiff test). This is a classic feature of BV, so this statement is also true.

D. Due to Gardnerella vaginalis:
Gardnerella vaginalis is the main organism associated with BV. Its overgrowth, along with other anaerobes, leads to the clinical features, making this statement correct.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, 3 weeks postpartum, presents with persistent vaginal bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

RPOC occurs when placental or fetal tissue remains in the uterus after delivery.

Typical presentation: persistent or heavy postpartum bleeding, sometimes uterine tenderness.

Most cases present within the first few weeks postpartum, exactly like this patient at 3 weeks.

Diagnosis is usually confirmed with ultrasound, showing echogenic material in the uterine cavity.

Management often involves uterine evacuation (suction curettage or medical management).

Other options:

B – Choriocarcinoma:

Rare malignant trophoblastic tumor.

Usually presents with bleeding, high β-hCG, and sometimes metastasis.

Onset is usually months after pregnancy, not just 3 weeks postpartum.

C – Uterine vascular anomaly (e.g., AV malformation):

Can cause prolonged or heavy bleeding.

Often diagnosed later, sometimes after surgical evacuation or in multiparous women.

Rare in early postpartum period compared to RPOC.

D – New pregnancy:

Unlikely at 3 weeks postpartum unless she ovulated very early.

Early pregnancy may cause spotting, but persistent heavy bleeding is uncommon.

β-hCG testing would confirm or rule out.

questions.text: A 26/M presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion for 5 months. He is a stone crusher. He had a long‐standing cough with whitish sputum production, but denied fever, chills, weight loss, night sweats, and other symptoms. The patient undergoes bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage. The effluent appears milky. The cytopathology shows amorphous debris with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)–positive macrophages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

PAP is a rare lung disease characterized by accumulation of surfactant material in alveoli, impairing gas exchange.

Clinical features: progressive dyspnea, dry cough, fatigue, and sometimes mild sputum.

Occupational exposure (stone crushing → silica) is a known risk factor for secondary PAP.

Diagnostic clue:

Bronchoalveolar lavage is milky.

PAS-positive material in alveolar macrophages confirms the diagnosis.

Chest imaging often shows “crazy-paving” pattern on CT (ground-glass opacities with interlobular septal thickening).

Other options:

A – Tuberculosis:

Usually presents with fever, night sweats, weight loss, and sometimes hemoptysis.

BAL may show acid-fast bacilli, not PAS-positive material.

Chronic cough alone without systemic symptoms is less suggestive of TB.

B – Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia (COP):

Usually presents with subacute cough, fever, malaise, sometimes following infection.

Imaging shows patchy peripheral consolidation, not milky BAL.

Histopathology shows intra-alveolar buds of granulation tissue, not PAS-positive debris.

C – ARDS:

Acute onset of severe hypoxemia and respiratory failure following a trigger (sepsis, trauma, pneumonia).

BAL is not characteristically milky, and onset is acute, not chronic over months

choices.text: Seizures presenting as a status epilepticus
Seizures associated with Postictal Todd’s paralysis

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors associated with recurrent seizures EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Risk factors associated with recurrent seizures are 
• Seizures presenting as a status epilepticus 
• Seizures associated with Postictal Todd’s paralysis 
• Strong family history of seizures 
• An abnormal focal neurologic examination 
• An abnormal EEG

questions.text: Anifrolumab is approved for the management of moderate to severe SLE. It is a biological agent – monoclonal antibody against the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Anifrolumab is a monoclonal antibody against Interferon type 1 receptor blocking the effects of both Interferon alpha and beta. It is approved for management of moderate to severe SLE on standard regimen.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with nephritic range proteinuria is found to have low serum complement levels. Which of the following can be the likely etiology? 
1. Systemic lupus erythematosus 
2. Post- Streptococcal glomerulonephritis 
3. Infective endocarditis 
4. IgA nephropathy 
Select the correct
answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

1 – Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):

SLE commonly causes immune complex–mediated glomerulonephritis.

Hypocomplementemia (low C3 and/or C4) is typical in active lupus nephritis, especially class III, IV, or V.

Presents with proteinuria, hematuria, and nephritic or nephrotic features.

2 – Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN):

Classic nephritic syndrome occurs 2–3 weeks after a streptococcal infection.

Low C3 is a hallmark, usually transient, while C4 is often normal.

Clinical features: hematuria, edema, hypertension, mild proteinuria.

3 – Infective Endocarditis (IE):

IE can cause immune complex–mediated glomerulonephritis, leading to low complement levels.

Usually presents with proteinuria, hematuria, systemic signs of infection.

Incorrect option:

4 – IgA Nephropathy:

IgA nephropathy usually presents with hematuria (often episodic), sometimes with mild proteinuria.

Serum complement levels are typically normal, making it unlikely in this case

choices.text: Breastfeeding with antiretroviral therapy for the baby

questions.text: A 28-year-old HIV-positive woman, who delivered a baby vaginally, wants to breastfeed her newborn. Which of the following is the recommended approach as per national guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

WHO and national guidelines recommend exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months even in HIV-positive mothers, provided:

The mother is on effective antiretroviral therapy (ART).

There is adequate follow-up and monitoring of both mother and baby.

Exclusive breastfeeding reduces HIV transmission risk compared to mixed feeding and provides optimal nutrition and immunity to the infant.

After 6 months, complementary feeding is introduced while continuing ART and breastfeeding up to 12 months or as advised.

Other options:

B – Formula feeding:

Recommended only if safe water and proper formula feeding practices are available.

In resource-limited settings, formula feeding carries higher risk of infections and malnutrition.

C – Mixed feeding:

Combination of breast milk and other foods in the first 6 months increases risk of HIV transmission.

Not recommended.

D – Breastfeeding with antiretroviral therapy for the baby:

ART prophylaxis is given to the infant, but the primary approach is maternal ART with exclusive breastfeeding.

Exclusive breastfeeding by itself is the key recommendation; ART for the baby is additional protection, not the sole strategy.

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with spontaneous mucosal bleeding and gum hypertrophy. Blood examination reveals Hb 10 g/dl, Platelet count 20,000, and 30% blasts. Coagulation studies are as follows PT 20 Sec, APTT 65 Sec. Fibrinogen levels are low. The blasts are more likely to show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clinical clues: spontaneous mucosal bleeding, gum hypertrophy, pancytopenia, and coagulopathy with prolonged PT, APTT, and low fibrinogen.

Lab findings suggest disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which is characteristic of APL.

t(15;17) is the translocation between the PML gene on chromosome 15 and RARA gene on chromosome 17, pathognomonic for APL.

Morphology: Promyelocytes with heavy granulation and Auer rods.

Early recognition is critical because treatment with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) rapidly reverses coagulopathy.

Other options:

A – t(9;22) (BCR-ABL, CML or Ph+ ALL):

Typically seen in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia or Philadelphia-positive ALL.

Does not usually present with DIC, gum hypertrophy, or severe mucosal bleeding.

B – t(8;21) (AML M2 subtype):

Often presents with myeloblasts with maturation, and less coagulopathy.

Associated with extramedullary involvement like chloromas, but not severe DIC.

C – t(16;16) (inv(16), AML M4Eo subtype):

Presents with myelomonocytic leukemia with eosinophilia.

Coagulopathy is rare, and gum hypertrophy is uncommon

choices.text: Empty Sella who do not have DI.

questions.text: Pituitary bright spot is absent in patients with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

In MRI of pituitary & hypothalamus of healthy beings, posterior pituitary emits a hyperintense signal on T1 weighted mid sagittal images. The pituitary bright spot is almost always present in patients with primary polydipsia but invariably absent or abnormally small in patients with pituitary DI. It is small or absent in nephrogenic DI because of high secretion & turnover
of vasopressin. Also seen absent in empty Sella with no DI.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man’s wife suddenly noticed his slurring of speech and right arm weakness which completely resolved in 30 minutes. He has a history of diabetes. His blood pressure is normal. Which of the following best represents his ABCD2 score.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ABCD2 Scoring System

Stepwise calculation for this patient:

  1. Age ≥60: 75 → 1 point

  2. BP ≥140/90: Normal → 0 points

  3. Clinical features: Right arm weakness (unilateral) → 2 points

  4. Duration: 30 minutes → 1 point

  5. Diabetes: Present → 1 point

Total ABCD² score: 1 (age) + 0 (BP) + 2 (clinical) + 1 (duration) + 1 (diabetes) = 5

questions.text: Which of the following is a benign tumor of blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Hemangioma is a benign vascular tumor arising from endothelial cells of blood vessels.

Commonly seen in infancy and childhood, often regresses spontaneously.

Types: capillary hemangioma, cavernous hemangioma, and mixed types.

Usually painless, soft, and red or bluish lesions.

Other options:

A – Angiosarcoma:

Malignant tumor of blood vessels.

Rapidly growing, aggressive, and may occur in skin, breast, liver, or spleen.

Poor prognosis.

B – Leiomyosarcoma:

Malignant tumor of smooth muscle, not blood vessels.

Can occur in uterus, retroperitoneum, or extremities.

D – Kaposi sarcoma:

Low-grade malignant vascular tumor, associated with HHV-8, commonly seen in HIV/AIDS patients.

Can present with cutaneous lesions, oral involvement, or visceral disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation has a blood pressure of 160/105 mmHg, proteinuria of 1.2 g/24 hours, and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following best describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Preeclampsia is defined as new-onset hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks gestation with proteinuria or end-organ dysfunction.

Severe features include:

BP ≥160/110 mmHg

Elevated liver enzymes (AST or ALT >2× normal)

Thrombocytopenia (<100,000/µL)

Renal insufficiency, pulmonary edema, or neurologic symptoms

This patient has:

BP 160/105 mmHg → meets severe threshold

Elevated liver enzymes → organ involvement

Proteinuria 1.2 g/24h → confirms preeclampsia


Other options:

A – Gestational hypertension:

Hypertension after 20 weeks without proteinuria or severe features.

This patient has proteinuria and liver involvement, so this is incorrect.

B – Preeclampsia without severe features:

Hypertension 140–159/90–109 mmHg and proteinuria without organ dysfunction.

Patient’s BP ≥160/105 and liver enzymes elevated, so this qualifies as severe features.

D – Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia:

Requires history of hypertension before 20 weeks gestation.

No prior history mentioned, so this is unlikely.

questions.text:
A 55 year hypertensive atherosclerotic patient presents with severe chest pain radiating to left shoulder. The pain is not related to exertion or any emotional stress and is present at rest. The pain disappears immediately after sublingual sorbitrate. Which of the following mediators is responsible
for such an episode?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The patient’s symptoms describe unstable angina / variant (Prinzmetal) angina, characterized by:

Chest pain at rest (not related to exertion)

Prompt relief with sublingual nitroglycerin

Pathophysiology:

In variant angina, coronary artery spasm is triggered.

Thromboxane A₂, produced by platelets and damaged endothelium, is a potent vasoconstrictor and promotes platelet aggregation.

This leads to transient myocardial ischemia, causing chest pain at rest.

Other options:

A – Prostaglandin E₂:

Vasodilator, involved in inflammation and fever, not responsible for coronary spasm.

B – IL-1:

Pro-inflammatory cytokine, mediates fever and systemic inflammation, not acute coronary vasospasm.

D – Complement 3a:

Anaphylatoxin, involved in immune-mediated inflammation and mast cell activation, not directly in coronary vasospasm.

choices.text: Middle cerebral artery (MCA) peak systolic velocity

questions.text: A 24-week twin pregnancy is diagnosed with twin anemia polycythemia sequence (TAPS). Which of the following diagnostic criteria would be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Middle cerebral artery (MCA) peak systolic velocity is the primary diagnostic tool for TAPS. In TAPS, one twin develops anemia and the other polycythemia due to chronic, slow transfusion of blood through small placental vascular connections. Anemic fetuses show increased MCA peak systolic velocity, while polycythemic fetuses may show decreased MCA velocity. Doppler assessment of MCA velocities is non-invasive, reliable, and widely used for early detection of TAPS.

Incorrect Options:

A. Simultaneous oligohydramnios and polyhydramnios:
