This is a hallmark of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), not TAPS. TAPS usually occurs without significant amniotic fluid discordance, so this criterion does not apply.

C. Presence of an artery–artery anastomosis:
While artery–artery (AA) anastomoses may exist, their presence alone is not diagnostic for TAPS. The diagnosis relies on hemodynamic assessment (MCA velocities) rather than anatomy.

D. Discordant growth between the twins:
Fetal growth discordance may occur in multiple pregnancies but is not specific for TAPS. In TAPS, the primary issue is hemoglobin imbalance, not size difference.

questions.text: Following inflammatory arthritis maybe associated with Anterior uveitis EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Correct Response 

(A): Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic systemic autoimmune disease primarily affecting synovial joints. Although RA can have systemic manifestations, anterior uveitis is not commonly associated with RA. Eye involvement in RA usually presents as keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes), scleritis, or episcleritis, rather than anterior uveitis. Therefore, RA is the exception among these inflammatory arthritides.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms during pregnancy indicates possible underlying heart disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Correct Answer (D) – All of the above:

Pregnancy imposes a hemodynamic burden on the cardiovascular system: increased blood volume, cardiac output, and heart rate.

While mild dyspnea is common in normal pregnancy, progressive or severe symptoms may indicate underlying heart disease.

Key symptoms suggesting cardiac involvement:

A – Progressive dyspnea:

Normal pregnancy may cause mild exertional dyspnea, but progressive or worsening shortness of breath is concerning.

Could indicate heart failure, valvular disease, or cardiomyopathy.

B – Chest pain:

Could reflect ischemia, pulmonary embolism, or peripartum cardiomyopathy.

Any atypical or severe chest pain during pregnancy warrants cardiac evaluation.

C – Orthopnea:

Difficulty breathing when lying flat is a classic heart failure symptom.

Not a normal feature of pregnancy and indicates possible cardiac dysfunction

choices.text: It is an Autosomal dominant defect
MRI screening for Berry Aneursym is indicated

questions.text: A young male presents with history of episodic hematuria associated with deafness. On examination, he has a subcapsular cataract. Which of the following is expected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

All are false statements The case described is Alports syndrome which is a X-linked defect of COL4A5 gene defect. It presents with the triad of Episodic hematuria, Deafness and lens defect. Berry Aneursym in brain, Hyperoxaluria, MVP, EPO-secreting tumour are all defects associated with ADPKD- Autosomal dominant forms of polycystic kidney disease.

questions.text: In which of the following women colpoclesis will done
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Prolapse with comorbidities Colpocleisis is a surgical procedure used to treat advanced pelvic organ prolapse by closing the vaginal canal, making it suitable only for women who no longer desire vaginal intercourse. It is especially indicated in elderly women with severe prolapse who are not good surgical candidates due to multiple comorbidities such as cardiac disease,
respiratory issues, or other conditions that make prolonged or invasive surgery risky. 

Since colpocleisis is a quick, low-risk procedure with minimal blood loss and recovery time, it is ideal for frail, elderly women who need definitive prolapse treatment but cannot tolerate more complex reconstructive surgeries.

choices.text: A protein derived from leakage of blood vessels

questions.text: A routine H&E histologic section from an irregular white area within the anterior wall of the heart of a 71-year-old male who died secondary to ischemic heart disease reveals the myocytes to be replaced by diffuse red material. This material stains blue with a trichrome stain. Which one of the listed statements correctly describes this material?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The patient has ischemic heart disease, and the anterior wall shows white area → likely myocardial infarction (MI) scar.

H&E shows myocytes replaced by red material, and trichrome stain turns it blue → this indicates collagen deposition, characteristic of fibrosis.

Collagen is produced by fibroblasts during healing and scar formation.

This is part of the repair process after MI, replacing necrotic myocytes with fibrous tissue.

Other options:

A – A misfolded normal protein:

Refers to amyloid, which stains Congo red with apple-green birefringence, not trichrome.

B – A protein derived from leakage of blood vessels:

Fibrin from hemorrhage stains differently; this is not typical for post-MI scar.

C – A protein from dead cells:

Necrotic myocyte proteins are degraded and not the blue-staining material in trichrome.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance as his family found him unresponsive at home. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse and human immune deficiency virus (HIV) with medical noncompliance. His last CD4 count was <200/μL. On initial evaluation, his BP 120/75 mmHg, Pulse 105 bpm, respiratory rate 8/min, ABG on room air reveals pH:
7.16, PaCO2 : 70 mmHg & PaO2 : 55 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Key features:

Unresponsiveness

Respiratory rate 8/min → severe hypoventilation

ABG: pH 7.16 (acidotic), PaCO₂ 70 mmHg (hypercapnia), PaO₂ 55 mmHg (hypoxemia) → respiratory acidosis

Narcotics (opioids) depress the central respiratory drive, causing hypoventilation, CO₂ retention, and hypoxemia.

Acute onset in IV drug user with low respiratory rate strongly suggests opioid overdose.

Management: airway support and naloxone.

Other options:

A – Asthma:

Usually presents with wheezing, dyspnea, tachypnea, not severe hypoventilation and unresponsiveness.

ABG typically shows hypoxemia with low PaCO₂ initially due to hyperventilation.

C – Pneumococcal pneumonia:

Causes fever, cough, productive sputum, dyspnea.

ABG shows hypoxemia, but PaCO₂ is usually normal or low due to compensatory hyperventilation.

Does not typically cause severe hypoventilation and acute unresponsiveness.

D – Pneumocystis pneumonia:

Common in HIV patients with CD4 <200, presents with progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and hypoxemia.

ABG: hypoxemia, but PaCO₂ is usually normal or low, unless late-stage respiratory failure.

Onset is subacute, not sudden collapse.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a positive urine pregnancy test and amenorrhea has no other complaints. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

A positive urine pregnancy test indicates the presence of hCG, which strongly suggests pregnancy.

Clinical management principle: Any woman with a positive pregnancy test should be considered pregnant until proven otherwise.

This approach ensures early precautions, such as avoiding teratogenic drugs, alcohol, or unsafe procedures.

Subsequent steps may include: confirming gestational age, assessing viability, and ruling out ectopic pregnancy.

Other options:

A – Perform a pelvic examination:

A pelvic exam is not the first step in a confirmed or suspected pregnancy.

It may be done later for gestational assessment, but assuming pregnancy first is safer.

B – Order an ultrasound scan:

Ultrasound can confirm intrauterine pregnancy, determine gestational age, and check for viability.

However, the immediate step is to assume pregnancy, not to delay management for imaging.

D – Repeat the urine pregnancy test:

Unnecessary if the initial test is positive and reliable.

Delays appropriate care without adding value.

choices.text: No cervical change for 4 hours with adequate contractions
No cervical change for 6 hours with inadequate contractions
Membranes ruptured and normal fetal heart rate

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a criterion for the diagnosis of arrest of active phase of labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Active phase of labor is defined as cervical dilation ≥6 cm with regular contractions.

Arrest of active phase is diagnosed only after entering the active phase.

If the cervix is less than 6 cm (e.g., <5 cm), the woman is still in the latent phase, so arrest of active phase cannot be diagnosed.

Other options (criteria for arrest of active phase):

A – No cervical change for 4 hours with adequate contractions:

Adequate contractions: ≥200 Montevideo units in 10 minutes

No cervical progress for ≥4 hours with adequate contractions → diagnostic for active phase arrest

B – No cervical change for 6 hours with inadequate contractions:

If contractions are inadequate, labor can be considered arrested if no cervical change for ≥6 hours, usually after augmentation attempts

D – Membranes ruptured and normal fetal heart rate:

Ensures fetal well-being before considering operative intervention.

Presence of intact membranes or abnormal fetal heart rate may alter management

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a palpable breast lump. Histopathology reveals a well-circumscribed, encapsulated tumor arising from the intralobular stroma. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Fibroadenoma is the most common benign breast tumor in women of reproductive age, but can occur in middle age.

Histology:

Well-circumscribed, encapsulated

Arises from intralobular stroma

Shows proliferation of both stromal and epithelial components

Clinical: Usually painless, firm, mobile lump, “rubbery” in consistency.

Other options:

A – Lipoma:

Benign tumor of adipose tissue

Histology: mature fat cells, not from intralobular stroma

Soft, non-tender, mobile mass

C – Fat necrosis:

Usually follows trauma or surgery

Histology: necrotic adipose tissue, foamy macrophages, calcifications

May mimic malignancy clinically or on imaging

D – Adenosis:

Benign proliferation of acini within the lobule

Not a circumscribed, encapsulated tumor

Histology: increased glandular elements, may have microcalcifications

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset severe lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her vitals show a blood pressure of 85/50 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Key clinical features:

Acute, severe lower abdominal pain

Vaginal bleeding

Signs of hypovolemic shock: hypotension (BP 85/50 mmHg) and tachycardia (HR 110 bpm)

Pathophysiology:

Ectopic pregnancy (usually tubal) ruptures, leading to intra-abdominal bleeding

Management:

Immediate resuscitation and surgical intervention are required

Other options:

B – Threatened abortion:

Presents with vaginal bleeding, usually without severe pain or shock

Cervix is closed, and hemodynamics are typically stable

C – Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID):

Presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and vaginal discharge

Shock is rare unless severe sepsis occurs

No sudden onset associated with acute intra-abdominal hemorrhage

D – Corpus luteum hemorrhage:

Can cause mild-moderate unilateral pain, sometimes with hemoperitoneum

Usually less severe, and shock is uncommon unless large bleed occurs

questions.text: Which of the following is a morphological feature of reversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Reversible cell injury occurs when the stress or damage is mild or short-lived, allowing the cell to recover if the stimulus is removed.

Morphological features:

Cellular swelling (hydropic change): Due to failure of Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase, leading to water accumulation in the cytoplasm

Fatty change (steatosis): In some cells like hepatocytes

Cytoplasm may appear pale and vacuolated

Cell membrane and nucleus remain intact, so recovery is possible

Other options (features of irreversible injury):

A – Chromatin condensation (pyknosis):

Indicates irreversible cell injury → apoptosis or necrosis

B – Membrane rupture:

Occurs in necrosis, which is irreversible

Leads to inflammatory response

D – DNA fragmentation (karyorrhexis):

Also a sign of irreversible injury

Nucleus breaks into fragments during necrosis or apoptosis

choices.text: Pituitary tumor >4 cm with elevated PRL levels.
Any size pituitary adenoma with PRL > 1000 mcg/L .

questions.text: Macroprolactenemia refers to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

MACROPROLACTIN /BIG PROLACTIN refers to large polymeric form of PRL hormone .85 % of PRL is monomeric but serum also contains dimeric and polymeric forms which have reduced clearance in blood. These forms are usually caused by precipitation of PRL by antibodies in blood but these are less bioactive form .So they are suspected in patients with high PRL
levels with no symptoms

choices.text: Diagnosis is made by a 2-hour 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT)
All pregnant women undergo universal screening at first antenatal visit
If 2-hour OGTT value ≥200 mg/dL, it is labeled as overt diabetes
GDM increases the risk of congenital anomalies in the fetus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is INCORRECT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

GDM typically develops after the first trimester when fetal organogenesis is mostly complete.

Therefore, GDM itself does NOT significantly increase the risk of congenital anomalies.

In contrast, pre-existing diabetes (type 1 or type 2) before pregnancy does increase risk of fetal malformations.

Other options (correct statements):

A – Diagnosis by 2-hour 75g OGTT:

Standard method recommended by WHO and national guidelines

Fasting and 2-hour glucose values are used to diagnose GDM

B – Universal screening at first antenatal visit:

Early screening is recommended for high-risk women (obesity, prior GDM, family history, etc.)

Low-risk women are usually screened at 24–28 weeks

C – 2-hour OGTT ≥200 mg/dL labeled as overt diabetes:

If the OGTT value crosses 200 mg/dL, it is considered overt diabetes in pregnancy, not just GDM

questions.text: The complement pathway that is activated by antigen-antibody complexes is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Classical pathway Explanation: The classical pathway of complement is triggered by IgG or IgM bound to antigen, leading to C1 activation. This eventually generates C3 convertase and downstream effects like opsonization, chemotaxis, and cell lysis. The alternative and lectin pathways are antibody independent.

questions.text: Which of the following is taking origin from Infraglenoid tubercle :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The long head of the triceps brachii arises from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

Function: Extends the elbow and assists in shoulder extension and adduction.

The long head is the only head of triceps that crosses the shoulder joint, hence its origin from the scapula.

Other options:

A – Medial head of triceps:

Originates from the posterior surface of the humerus, inferior to the radial groove

Deep head, also does not cross the shoulder joint

B – Lateral head of triceps:

Originates from the posterior surface of the humerus, superior to the radial groove

Does not cross the shoulder joint

D – Biceps brachii:

Short head: Coracoid process of scapula

Long head: Supraglenoid tubercle of scapula

Biceps brachii is an elbow flexor, not a triceps head

questions.text: A patient presented with rashes in >30 percentage skin with hemorrhagic crusting on lips. The cause would be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Option A-Toxic epidermal necrolysis(TEN) occurs due to drug reaction,which is characterised by skin lesions + more than or equal to 2 mucosa involved such as oral ,genital, nasal, Ocular.This condition is characterised by:-

 Targetoid/ Target like lesions.
 Central zone is necrotic,  surrounded by zone of erythema in periphery.
 Targetoid lesions are also seen in  :
 <10>
 >30% BSA : TEN
 10 -30% BSA : SJS TEN OVERLAP

Drugs associated with severe drug rash can be remembered with a mnemonic Natural & Clear SOAP : 
Nevirapine, NSAIDS
CARBAMAZEPINE
SULPHA DRUGS
OXICAMS
ALLOPURINOL 
PHENYTOIN, PHENOBARBITONE, PENICILLIN GROUP. 

Option B,C,D-Viruses,Malignancy and bacterial infections can themselves cause TEN.But the most common cause is drugs.

choices.text: Chorda tympani in the middle ear cavity

questions.text: A 46-year-old man complains of dryness of the mouth. On examination he lack salivary secretion from the submandibular gland. This indicates a lesion of which of the following nervous structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The submandibular and sublingual salivary glands receive parasympathetic innervation via:

Preganglionic fibers from the facial nerve (CN VII)

Fibers travel via the chorda tympani in the middle ear cavity

Synapse at the submandibular ganglion → postganglionic fibers innervate the glands

Lesion of chorda tympani → loss of submandibular and sublingual gland secretion → xerostomia (dry mouth)

Other options:

A – Greater petrosal nerve:

Carries parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland, nasal, and palatine glands

Lesion → dry eyes and nasal mucosa, not submandibular gland

C – Superior cervical ganglion:

Provides sympathetic innervation to head and neck structures

Sympathetic stimulation → minor contribution to salivary secretion, mainly viscosity, not primary volume

D – Lesser petrosal nerve:

Carries parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland

Lesion → reduced parotid secretion, not submandibular gland

questions.text: Who has the power to grant complete pardon (amnesty) in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Article 72 of the Indian Constitution empowers the President to:

Grant pardon, reprieve, respite, or remission of punishment

Applies to offences against laws of India and court-martial cases

Types of clemency:

Pardon (full exemption from punishment)

Commutation (reduction of sentence)

Respite (temporary delay in sentence)

Remission (reduction in amount of sentence)

Scope:

Death penalty, imprisonment, or fines

Only the President can grant a complete pardon (amnesty)

Other options:

A – Chief Justice of India:

Judicial officer; cannot grant pardon or amnesty.

B – Prime Minister of India:

Advises the President on clemency but does not have independent power.

D – Home Minister of India:

Administrative head; can recommend but cannot grant pardon.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin increases intracellular cyclic AMP by activating adenylate cyclase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Cholera toxin is produced by Vibrio cholerae.

Mechanism:

Binds to GM1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells

The A subunit activates adenylate cyclase via ADP-ribosylation of Gs protein

Leads to increased intracellular cAMP

High cAMP → Cl⁻ and water secretion into the intestinal lumen → profuse watery diarrhea (“rice-water stools”)

Other options:

A – Tetanospasmin:

Produced by Clostridium tetani

Mechanism: blocks release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA, glycine) → spastic paralysis

Does not affect cAMP

B – Shiga toxin:

Produced by Shigella dysenteriae and some E. coli strains

Mechanism: inhibits protein synthesis by cleaving 28S rRNA → cell death

Does not increase cAMP

D – Diphtheria toxin:

Produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Mechanism: ADP-ribosylates EF-2, inhibiting protein synthesis → cell death

Does not affect cAMP

choices.text: S1 occurs immediately after end of T wave
S1 begins during the ST segment and ends before the T wave
S1 is heard simultaneously at the peak of R wave in all the leads
S1 starts 0.02- 0.04s after the onset of QRS complex

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding timing and correlation of S1 with the ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

S1 typically start 0.02 to 0.04 s after the onset of QRS complex. This slight delay represents the time between the electrical activation of the ventricles and mechanical closure of AV valves which produces S 1.

questions.text: Which virus contains reverse transcriptase but does not integrate into the host genome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
.
Hepatitis B virus Explanation: HBV is a DNA virus with reverse transcriptase activity. It replicates via an RNA intermediate, but unlike retroviruses, its genome does not obligatorily integrate into the host genome for replication. Integration can occur in chronic cases
and is linked to hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A women presents with pruritic rash on the elbows, buttocks with recent diagnosis of gluten sensitive enteropathy. On immunofluorescence IgA deposition is seen as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A patient with pruritic rash on the elbows, buttocks with recent diagnosis of gluten sensitive enteropathy. On immunofluorescence IgA deposition on the tip of dermal papilla, this is classical of dermatitis herpetiformis

questions.text: There is a history of prick with vegetative matter in a person after which he developed these linear lesions over his hand. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Option A-M. Scrofuloderma causes ulcer k/s scrofuloderma.

Option B-M. Ulcerans causes buruli ulcer.

Option C-The given image shows Linear, sporotrichoid pattern pf spread along the lymphatics.This is seen in Sporothrix schenckii following injury with rose thorn.Mycobacterium marinum & Nocardia can also present like this in a linear lymphatic pattern.

Option D-Phialophora species causes chromoblastomycosis.

questions.text: Most common vitamin deficiency post disaster is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common micronutrient deficiency following natural disasters, famines, or food shortages. This occurs because preformed vitamin A and beta-carotene sources (like milk, eggs, and vegetables) are often limited in emergency food supplies. Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, xerophthalmia, and increased susceptibility to infections, making it a critical public health concern post-disaster.

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent boy is being treated with the macrolide antibiotic erythromycin complains of nausea, intestinal cramping, and diarrhoea. The side effects are the result of the antibiotic binding to receptors in the GI tract that recognize which gastrointestinal hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Erythromycin group of drugs bind to motilin-like receptors in the GI tract. Motilin stimulates increased contractions by a direct action on smooth muscle and by activation of excitatory enteric nerves. This results in increased intestinal motility, abdominal cramping and diarrhoea.

questions.text:
Nail change(s) seen in psoriasis may include which among the following
A. Pitting
B. Nail plate thinning
C. Subungual hyperkeratosis
D. Oil drop sign
E. Pterygium formation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nail changes in psoriasis

  • Also remember that nail plate is thickened, not thinned in psoriasis
  • Pterygium is seen in lichen planus

questions.text: Maximum sample size is achieved for a particular confidence and absolute precision value; prevalence should be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: He loses voluntary control over his respiration
Central chemoreceptors will no longer be able to exert any control over the ventilation
Involuntary control over respiration will be lost but voluntary control will be present

questions.text: A 38-year-old male is brought to the Emergency after being thrown from his motorcycle following a collision with a stationary trolley. It is determined that he has a brain transection above the pons. How will this lesion affect the control of breathing in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Voluntary control of breathing originates in the cerebral cortex, which sends signals directly to spinal motor neurons controlling respiratory muscles.

A transection above the pons disconnects the cortical input from the brainstem respiratory centers, leading to loss of voluntary breathing.

Involuntary (automatic) breathing, mediated by the medulla and pons and modulated by chemoreceptors, remains intact if the medulla is preserved.

Other options:

A – All breathing movements will cease:

Incorrect: Automatic breathing is controlled by the medullary respiratory centers. If the medulla is intact, involuntary respiration continues.

C – Central chemoreceptors will no longer be able to exert control:

Incorrect: Central chemoreceptors in the medulla still function and respond to PaCO₂, regulating automatic breathing.

D – Involuntary control lost but voluntary control present:

Incorrect: Voluntary control is lost due to cortical disconnection, while involuntary control persists.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease is found unresponsive at home. Which of the following postmortem changes would be expected to occur first?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

First postmortem change is the cessation of all bodily functions, including:

Cardiac activity → no circulation

Respiration → no oxygen delivery

Brain activity → unconsciousness, loss of reflexes

This occurs immediately at death and precedes all visible postmortem changes.

Other options (occur later):

A – Rigor mortis:

Stiffening of muscles due to ATP depletion

Appears 2–6 hours after death, maximal at 12 hours, resolves after 24–48 hours

B – Livor mortis (hypostasis):

Purple discoloration of dependent body parts due to gravitational pooling of blood

Becomes visible 1–2 hours after death, fixed in 6–12 hours

C – Putrefaction:

Decomposition of tissues by bacteria

Begins 24–48 hours after death, varies with environment

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a vesicular rash over the left thorax in a dermatomal pattern. Which virus is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) causes chickenpox in primary infection and shingles (herpes zoster) upon reactivation, commonly in immunocompromised or elderly patients. Dermatomal vesicles are typical. HSV causes localized genital/oral lesions; CMV usually doesn't cause vesicles.

choices.text: Chloride shift causing swelling of red blood cells
Lower plasma volume in venous blood
Greater carbon dioxide content in venous blood

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to higher haematocrit in venous blood?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Venous blood hematocrit is slightly higher than arterial blood due to several factors:

Chloride shift (Hamburger phenomenon):

CO₂ enters red blood cells → converted to HCO₃⁻

HCO₃⁻ leaves RBC in exchange for Cl⁻

Causes slight RBC swelling and changes in volume distribution, affecting hematocrit

Lower plasma volume in venous blood:

Venous blood has higher protein concentration and lower plasma water

This increases the proportion of red cells → higher hematocrit

Greater CO₂ content in venous blood:

CO₂ binds to hemoglobin forming carbaminohemoglobin → increases RBC density

Contributes to higher hematocrit

Combined effect: venous hematocrit slightly higher than arterial hematocrit (~2–3% difference)

Other options:

Each factor alone contributes partially, but all combined explain the overall increase in venous hematocrit.

questions.text: World TB Day theme 2025 is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The theme for World Tuberculosis (TB) Day 2025 is "Yes! We Can End TB: Commit, Invest, Deliver". This theme emphasizes the urgent need for global commitment, increased investment, and decisive action to eliminate tuberculosis as a public health threat. It highlights the importance of collective efforts from governments, healthcare systems, and communities to achieve a TB-free future.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of sexual intercourse, and physical examination reveals a ruptured hymen. Which part of the hymen is most commonly ruptured during intercourse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The postero-lateral portion of the hymen is the most commonly ruptured during vaginal intercourse. This is due to the anatomical configuration of the hymenal tissue, which is thinner and more flexible at the posterolateral regions. During penetration, the mechanical force typically causes tearing in these weaker areas, while the anterior and lateral portions are more resistant. Recognizing this pattern is important in forensic and clinical examinations.

questions.text: A newborn has bilateral conjunctivitis 7 days after birth. Gram stain shows no organisms. What is the most likely cause and treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Inclusion conjunctivitis caused by C. trachomatis (D–K) occurs 5–14 days postnatally. Gram stain is negative due to its intracellular nature. Oral erythromycin is required to treat both conjunctivitis and potential pneumonia.

questions.text: The toxin responsible for gas gangrene has which principal enzymatic activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Gas gangrene is primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.

The major virulence factor is alpha toxin, which is a lecithinase (phospholipase C).

Mechanism: Hydrolyzes phosphatidylcholine (lecithin) in cell membranes → cell lysis, tissue necrosis, hemolysis, and myonecrosis.

Clinically, this leads to rapidly spreading muscle necrosis, gas formation, and systemic toxicity.

Other options:

A – DNase: Degrades DNA; minor spreading factor in some bacteria, not the main toxin in gas gangrene.

C – Adenylate cyclase: Found in Bordetella pertussis and Bacillus anthracis (edema factor), increases cAMP, not responsible for gas gangrene.

D – Neuraminidase: Facilitates bacterial spread in tissues, but not the principal enzymatic activity causing gas gangrene.

questions.text: In the logo of WHO, the leaf will have:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)  

The olive branch in the World Health Organization (WHO) logo symbolizes peace. The WHO emblem features a staff with a snake (from the Rod of Asclepius, symbolizing medicine) over a world map, flanked by olive branches, reflecting the organization’s mission to promote global health and harmony.

Other Options:

A. Neem is a medicinal tree widely used in India, but it is not part of the WHO logo.

C. Mahogany is a hardwood tree, unrelated to the symbolism of peace and health, so it is incorrect.

D. Chinar is a type of maple tree found in Kashmir; it has no connection to the WHO emblem.

questions.text: A traveller returns from South America with fever, swollen eyelid (Romaña sign), and cardiomegaly. Which stage of the organism is detected in blood during acute illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The patient’s presentation suggests acute Chagas disease caused by Trypanosoma cruzi.

Clinical features:

Fever, Romaña sign (periorbital swelling at site of inoculation)

Cardiomegaly in chronic phase

Life cycle:

Trypomastigotes: Circulating extracellular form in blood during acute infection → detected on peripheral blood smear

Amastigotes: Intracellular form in tissue cells (e.g., myocardium), not in circulating blood

Epimastigotes: Found in insect vector (reduviid bug), not in humans

Promastigotes: Form seen in Leishmania, not Trypanosoma cruzi

Other options:

A – Amastigote:

Intracellular form multiplying in tissues (heart, smooth muscle)

Not seen in peripheral blood

C – Promastigote:

Found in Leishmania spp. (sandfly stage)

Not part of human T. cruzi blood stage

D – Epimastigote:

Insect vector stage, replicates in midgut of reduviid bug

Not found in human blood

choices.text: Major Impact Indicator is reduction of IMR

questions.text: All are true for ASHA worker except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Only honorarium is given
Explanation

questions.text: A man returns from Brazil with skin ulcers, mucosal erosion, and enlarged lymph nodes. Microscopy of a biopsy shows amastigotes. What is the likely species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Clinical scenario:

Cutaneous lesions → skin ulcers

Mucosal involvement → nasal/oral erosion (mucocutaneous leishmaniasis)

Regional lymphadenopathy

Epidemiology:

Endemic in Central and South America, especially Brazil

Microscopy:

Amastigotes (intracellular, non-flagellated form) seen in macrophages of biopsy

Life cycle:

Amastigotes in humans → transform to promastigotes in sandfly vector

Other options:

A – Leishmania donovani:

Causes visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar)

Symptoms: fever, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia

Skin ulcers and mucosal lesions are not typical

C – Trypanosoma cruzi:

Causes Chagas disease

Symptoms: fever, Romaña sign, cardiomyopathy

Blood trypomastigotes, not tissue amastigotes in skin ulcers

D – Trypanosoma brucei:

Causes African sleeping sickness

Symptoms: chancre at bite site, systemic illness, CNS involvement

Endemic to sub-Saharan Africa, not Brazil

Amastigotes are not seen in humans

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with a genital ulcer. Dark-field microscopy reveals tightly coiled, motile spirochetes. He is allergic to penicillin. What is the alternative treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The patient has a genital ulcer with dark-field demonstration of motile, tightly coiled spirochetes, which is characteristic of Treponema pallidum (syphilis). The drug of choice for all stages of syphilis is benzathine penicillin G. However, in patients who are allergic to penicillin, the recommended alternative is doxycycline (a tetracycline antibiotic), which is effective against T. pallidum in early syphilis and is widely accepted as the next best option.

Incorrect Options:

A. Ceftriaxone – It is effective against T. pallidum and sometimes used as an alternative, but doxycycline is the more established and widely recommended substitute in penicillin-allergic patients. Ceftriaxone is usually reserved if doxycycline is contraindicated.

B. Azithromycin – Though once considered, macrolide resistance in T. pallidum is now common worldwide. Hence, it is not recommended for routine use.

D. Gentamicin – An aminoglycoside that has no role in the treatment of syphilis.

questions.text: A 29 year-old man comes in with a stab wound, cannot raise his arm above horizontal, and exhibits a condition known as winged scapula while pushing against the wall. Which of the following structures of the brachial plexus would most likely be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Winged scapula occurs due to paralysis of the serratus anterior.

Innervated by long thoracic nerve (C5–C7 roots)

Clinical signs:

Inability to raise the arm above horizontal → due to weak scapular rotation

Medial border of scapula protrudes when pushing against a wall (winged scapula)

Mechanism in this case:

Stab wound likely injured roots of brachial plexus supplying long thoracic nerve

Other options:

A – Medial cord:

Gives rise to medial pectoral nerve, ulnar nerve, medial brachial and antebrachial cutaneous nerves

Injury → weakness of intrinsic hand muscles or pectoralis minor/major, not serratus anterior

B – Posterior cord:

Gives rise to axillary, radial, upper/lower subscapular nerves, thoracodorsal nerve

Injury → deltoid, teres minor, latissimus dorsi weakness, not winged scapula

C – Lower trunk:

Formed by C8–T1

Injury → claw hand, intrinsic hand muscle weakness, not serratus anterior paralysis

questions.text: The Left superior intercostal vein drains into :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

• The 1st left posterior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein. 

• The 2nd , 3rd , & 4th left posterior intercostal veins join to form the left superior intercostals vein that drains into the left brachiocephalic vein. 

• The 5th , 6th, 7th& 8th join to form the accessory hemiazygous vein which drain in the azygous vein 

• The 9th, 10th , 11th& 12th join to form the hemiazygous vein which also drain into the azygous vein.

questions.text: In a case of inorganic lead poisoning, what is the most common route of lead absorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

In inorganic lead poisoning, the most common route of absorption is inhalation, particularly in occupational settings such as smelting, battery manufacturing, and lead-based paint work. Fine lead dust or fumes are easily inhaled and absorbed through the lungs into the bloodstream, leading to systemic toxicity. Adults exposed to lead at work are more likely to be affected via inhalation than ingestion.

Incorrect Options:
A. Ingestion:
While ingestion is a significant route in children (from lead-containing paint, contaminated water, or food), in adults with occupational exposure, it is less common than inhalation.

C. Dermal absorption:
Lead does not readily penetrate intact skin, so dermal absorption is negligible.

D. Injection:
Injection is extremely rare and only occurs in accidental or experimental contexts.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man, victim of road traffic accident is brought to the Emergency and is diagnosed with hemi section of the left side of the spinal cord at C6. Which of the following function is likely to be lost in the right leg of this man?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A Person is not able to maintain balance immediately after roller Coster ride. Which of the following is most likely involved in normal balance maintenance ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The vestibulospinal tract is crucial for maintaining posture and balance. It originates from the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem and projects to spinal motor neurons to adjust limb and trunk muscles in response to changes in head position. After a roller coaster ride, the vestibular system detects rapid changes in motion and spatial orientation, and the vestibulospinal tract helps stabilize the body. Dysfunction or temporary overstimulation can lead to imbalance and unsteady gait.

Incorrect Options:
A. Corticospinal tract:
This tract is primarily responsible for voluntary motor control of limb muscles, not automatic balance adjustments.

B. Corticobulbar tract:
This tract controls voluntary movements of cranial muscles, such as facial and jaw muscles. It does not maintain balance.

D. Reticulospinal tract:
The reticulospinal tract contributes to posture and gross motor activity, but the vestibulospinal tract is the primary pathway for rapid balance corrections in response to vestibular input.

questions.text: A 32 year old female presented with heavy hairloss since few months. She gives history of suffering with COVID 19 eight month back. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Option A-This is a case of Telogen effluvium,which is a common type of hair loss that affects people after they experience severe stress or a change to their body. Symptoms include thinning hair, usually around the top of your head. Treatment exists to reverse hair loss, but hair will typically grow back in three to six months without treatment.

Option B-Female pattern hair loss leads to central balding,but there will be no history of stressor like fever.

Option C-Alopecia areata is an autoimmune disease that attacks your body’s hair follicles, causing patchy hair loss.It will be a well circumscribed patch with no erythema or inflammation.Again,there will be no history of stressor like fever.

Option D-Trichotillomania is when someone cannot resist the urge to pull out their hair. They may pull out the hair on their head or in other places, such as their eyebrows or eyelashes.It can present with tonsure sign.

questions.text: All except the following are component of juxta glomerular apparatus (JGA)-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) is a specialized structure in the renal cortex that regulates glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renin secretion.

Components of JGA:

Afferent arteriole: Contains juxtaglomerular (granular) cells that secrete renin

Macula densa: Specialized cells of distal convoluted tubule that sense Na⁺ and Cl⁻ concentration

Extraglomerular mesangial cells (Lacis cells): Connect afferent arteriole and macula densa; help in signal transmission

Loop of Henle:

Descending and ascending limbs are part of the nephron, but not a structural component of JGA

Only distal convoluted tubule (macula densa) is involved in JGA

Other options:

A – Afferent arteriole:

Contains granular cells → renin secretion → regulates blood pressure

B – Macula densa:

Senses Na⁺ concentration in distal tubule → triggers tubuloglomerular feedback

C – Extraglomerular mesangial cells:

Provide communication between macula densa and afferent arteriole

questions.text:
A medical student is studying the fluid exchange in skeletal muscle capillaries in a laboratory animal.

He determines that fluid is being filtered out of the capillaries with a net filtration pressure of
10mmHg. He obtains the following values –

Capillary hydrostatic pressure is 45mmHg

Capillary oncotic pressure is 25 mmHg

Interstitial oncotic pressure is 10mmHg

Which of the following is the interstitial hydrostatic pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Starling forces govern the rate of filtration across capillaries. It depends on four pressures – capillary hydrostatic pressure, capillary oncotic pressure, interstitial hydrostatic pressure and interstitial oncotic pressure. So, NFP= PCap + πIF – PIF – πcap . From the above data, 10= 45+ 10 – 25 + πIF = 30 + πIF , hence πIF= 20mmHg.

questions.text: What is the ideal period of contraception advisable after treatment with isotretinoin to avoid any teratogenic effects of the drug on the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Following treatment with isotretinoin, it is crucial to continue using effective contraception for at least 3 months after the last dose. This extended period is necessary because isotretinoin has a long half-life and can remain in the body for an extended time. If a woman were to become pregnant during this window, the drug's teratogenic effects could still cause severe and life-threatening birth defects in the fetus. This strict recommendation is a key component of the iPLEDGE program, which is a risk management program designed to prevent fetal exposure to isotretinoin.

questions.text: Carriers are source of infection for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Meningococcal meningitis
Explanation

questions.text: A 4-year-old child brought with sore throat since 2 days. On examination, there are multiple vesicles on palm, sole and oral mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent causing the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The child has classic features of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD):

Oral vesicles (enanthem)

Vesicular rash on palms and soles (exanthem)

Mild systemic symptoms: fever, sore throat

Etiological agent:

Coxsackievirus A16, a member of Enterovirus genus

Transmission: Fecal-oral or respiratory droplets

Course: Usually self-limiting in children <5 years

Other options:

B – Varicella zoster virus:

Causes chickenpox

Vesicles are generalized, mostly trunk and face, not specifically palms and soles

Oral lesions occur but distribution is different

C – Human herpesvirus-6:

Causes roseola infantum

Features: High fever for 3–5 days followed by maculopapular rash, not vesicular

Vesicles on palms and soles are not typical

D – Enterovirus:

General genus; Coxsackie A16 is a type of enterovirus

Option D is too broad; A16 is more specific and classic cause

questions.text: BMW does not apply to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Biomedical Waste (BMW): Refers to waste generated during diagnosis, treatment, or immunization of humans or animals, including sharps, blood, body fluids, cultures, and discarded medical instruments.

Not included in BMW:

Radioactive wastes: Managed under Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) guidelines

Lead-acid batteries: Classified as hazardous industrial waste, handled separately under hazardous waste rules

Electronic wastes (e-wastes): Covered under e-waste management rules, not BMW

Key point: BMW rules do not cover these non-biological hazardous wastes

Other options:

A, B, C individually: Each is outside the scope of biomedical waste

D – All of these: Correct as all listed items are not covered under BMW

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a sign of deep frostbite?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Paradoxical undressing is not a feature of deep frostbite; it is associated with severe hypothermia, typically in the late stages. In hypothermia, individuals may feel a false sense of warmth and remove clothing, which is a dangerous sign of critical core temperature drop. This is unrelated to the local tissue injury seen in frostbite.

Incorrect Options:
A. Formation of ice crystals:
In deep frostbite, ice crystals form within tissues, causing cellular damage and necrosis. This is a hallmark of deep tissue freezing.

B. Development of blisters:
Blisters, especially hemorrhagic blisters, are common in deep frostbite and indicate damage to deeper dermal layers.

C. Gangrene:
Deep frostbite can lead to tissue death and gangrene if circulation is not restored, particularly in extremities.

choices.text: At the base –PO2 is lowest and PCO2 is highest
At the apex- PO2 is lowest and PCO2 is highest
At the middle –PO2 is lowest and PCO2 is highest
At the base- PO2 is highest and PCO2 is lowest

questions.text: What are the expected partial pressures of oxygen and carbon dioxide at the apex, middle and basal portions of the lungs in a person in erect posture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • Mechanism:

    1. Perfusion increases more than ventilation from apex → base

    2. V/Q ratio at base <1> → less oxygen, more carbon dioxide

    3. Apex: V/Q >1 → higher PO₂, lower PCO₂

  • Result:

    • Base: PO₂ lowest (~90 mmHg), PCO₂ highest (~45 mmHg)

    • Apex: PO₂ highest (~100 mmHg), PCO₂ lowest (~35 mmHg)

questions.text: What is the primary role of dendritic cells in the immune system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Dendritic cells (DCs) are professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

Key functions:

Capture antigens from pathogens or damaged cells

Process antigens into peptides

Present antigenic peptides via MHC molecules to naive T cells in lymph nodes

Provide co-stimulatory signals → activation of adaptive immunity

Role in immune response:

Initiates primary T-cell responses

Bridges innate and adaptive immunity

Other options:

A – Producing antibodies:

Incorrect: Antibodies are produced by B cells/plasma cells, not dendritic cells

C – Destroying infected cells:

Incorrect: Cytotoxic T cells and NK cells perform this function

D – Producing cytokines:

Partially correct: Dendritic cells can secrete cytokines to modulate immune response, but this is secondary to their main role of antigen presentation

questions.text: A patient presents with severe iron toxicity after ingesting ferrous sulfate tablets. What is the specific treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Desferrioxamine is a specific iron chelator used in cases of acute iron toxicity. It binds free iron in the blood to form a water-soluble complex called ferrioxamine, which is then excreted in the urine (sometimes giving a characteristic “rust-colored” urine). This treatment is indicated in patients with severe iron poisoning, typically with serum iron >500 µg/dL or significant clinical toxicity (e.g., metabolic acidosis, shock).

Incorrect Options:
A. N-acetylcysteine:
This is the antidote for acetaminophen (paracetamol) toxicity, not iron poisoning.

C. Dimercaprol (BAL):
Dimercaprol is used for arsenic, gold, and inorganic mercury poisoning, but it is not effective for iron toxicity.

D. Succimer:
Succimer (DMSA) is an oral chelator used mainly for lead poisoning; it has no role in acute iron overdose.

choices.text: Gluteus Maximus, Gluteus Medius and Gluteus Minimus

questions.text: Positive Trendelenburg sign indicates of which group of gluteus muscles :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Trendelenburg test: Patient stands on one leg.

Positive sign: Pelvis drops on the contralateral side when standing on the affected leg.

Muscles involved:

Gluteus medius and minimus are primary hip abductors and stabilize the pelvis during single-leg stance.

Weakness → inability to maintain level pelvis, causing Trendelenburg gait

Other options:

B – Gluteus maximus and minimus:

Gluteus maximus is a hip extensor, not a primary abductor → does not directly affect Trendelenburg sign

C – Gluteus maximus and medius:

Maximus contributes to extension, not pelvis stabilization in single-leg stance

D – Gluteus maximus, medius, and minimus:

Maximus not essential for positive Trendelenburg sign; main muscles are medius and minimus

questions.text: A worker in a metal smelting factory presents with severe bone pain, muscular cramps, and renal dysfunction. Which metal poisoning is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cadmium poisoning commonly occurs in workers exposed to cadmium fumes in metal smelting or battery manufacturing. Chronic cadmium exposure primarily affects the bones and kidneys. It can cause:
• Bone pain and fractures (due to cadmium-induced osteomalacia and demineralization)
• Muscular cramps
• Renal dysfunction (proteinuria and tubular damage)

The classic “Itai-Itai disease” in Japan was caused by chronic cadmium exposure from contaminated rice, leading to osteomalacia and renal failure, matching the patient’s presentation.

Incorrect Options:
A. Lead poisoning:
Lead mainly causes neurological symptoms, anemia, and gastrointestinal disturbances. Chronic exposure can affect bones, but renal and bone involvement is less prominent than cadmium.

B. Arsenic poisoning:
Arsenic toxicity typically presents with skin changes, neuropathy, and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than primary bone and kidney disease.

D. Mercury poisoning:
Mercury mainly affects the nervous system and kidneys, but does not typically cause severe bone pain or osteomalacia.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the marked area
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

• The radial nerve provides both motor and sensory functions to the arm, forearm, and hand.

• The sensory function of the radial nerve, via its superficial branch, supplies the skin on the posterior (dorsal) aspect of the hand.

• Specifically, this includes the back of the hand, thumb, index finger, middle finger, and the lateral half of the ring finger.

• The marked area in the image, which includes the back of the hand and the thumb and index finger region, corresponds precisely to the sensory distribution of the superficial branch of the radial nerve.

Other options
• A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve provides sensory innervation to the dorsal aspect of the little finger and the medial half of the ring finger.

• B. Median nerve: The median nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the palm of the hand and the ventral (palmar) surfaces of the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and the lateral half of the ring finger.

• D. Posterior interosseous nerve: The posterior interosseous nerve is a purely motor branch of the radial nerve and has no sensory function in the hand. It innervates the extensor muscles in the forearm.

questions.text: A middle-aged women complained that her right-hand tremors when she attempts to insert a thread in the eye of sewing needle; and her body sways towards the right side while walking. On physical examination the Physician found that: there is flaccidity of limb muscles on the right side, and when she was asked to touch the tip of her nose with her right index finger, the finger tended to overshoot the target. Which part of the Brain is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Clinical features suggest cerebellar dysfunction:

Intention tremor: Tremor occurs during voluntary movement (e.g., threading a needle)

Ataxia / swaying: Body tends to fall towards the side of lesion → ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere involvement

Flaccidity / hypotonia: Cerebellar lesions reduce muscle tone

Dysmetria / past-pointing: Overshooting or undershooting movements when performing finger-to-nose test

Localization:

Right-sided symptoms → right cerebellar hemisphere lesion

Cerebellum coordinates voluntary movement, balance, and posture

Other options:

A – Basal nuclei:

Causes resting tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia (Parkinsonian features)

No intention tremor or hypotonia

B – Thalamus:

Lesions cause sensory deficits, thalamic pain, or motor hemiparesis, but not intention tremor or ataxia

D – Cerebrum:

Cerebral lesions → contralateral weakness, sensory loss, or cognitive deficits

Do not cause intention tremor, hypotonia, or dysmetria

questions.text: A woman in late pregnancy is found to be IgM positive for Toxoplasma gondii. What fetal abnormality is most likely if vertical transmission occurs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The presence of IgM antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii in a pregnant woman indicates recent or acute infection, which carries a risk of vertical transmission to the fetus.

Toxoplasmosis in pregnancy can lead to congenital toxoplasmosis, the classic triad of which includes:

Chorioretinitis – inflammation of the choroid and retina, leading to visual impairment; the most common ocular manifestation.

Hydrocephalus – due to obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow.

Intracranial calcifications – usually periventricular.

Other findings can include jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and seizures, but chorioretinitis is the hallmark ocular lesion.

Incorrect options:

A. Renal agenesis: Not associated with toxoplasmosis; more commonly seen in genetic syndromes or environmental teratogens like ACE inhibitors in early pregnancy.

B. Cataracts: Typically seen in congenital rubella or galactosemia, not toxoplasmosis.

D. Club foot: A nonspecific musculoskeletal malformation; not a typical feature of congenital toxoplasmosis.

choices.text: An insane person is always considered criminally responsible.
An insane person is never considered criminally responsible.
Criminal responsibility depends on the presence or absence of 'insight' into the act.
Criminal responsibility is determined solely by the severity of the mental illness.

questions.text: According to Section 22 of the BNF, which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the criminal responsibility of an insane person?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Under Section 22 of the BNF, an individual with mental illness may be criminally responsible if they have sufficient insight to understand the nature and consequences of their act at the time of the offense. The law focuses on the cognitive awareness and control over the act, rather than the mere presence of mental illness. This principle allows courts to distinguish between those who cannot comprehend their actions and those who can.

Incorrect Options:
A. An insane person is always considered criminally responsible:
This is false because mental illness can impair judgment or understanding, potentially removing criminal liability.

B. An insane person is never considered criminally responsible:
This is incorrect because not all mentally ill persons are devoid of insight; some may understand their actions and thus be held responsible.

D. Criminal responsibility is determined solely by the severity of the mental illness:
Severity alone does not determine liability; cognitive insight and understanding of the act are crucial.

questions.text: Number of beds in SNCU is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: The following MRI image shows a malignancy. What is the visual field defect observed in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Bitemporal hemianopia The given MRI shows a tumour protruding out of sella turcica. This is likely to be a pituitary tumour (pituitary macroadenoma) compressing the optic chiasma, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man has been experiencing worsening headaches and new-onset seizures. MRI with contrast was done and is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Glioblastoma The given MRI finding is suggestive of glioblastoma. Postcontrast MRI in the case of GBM demonstrates a large heterogeneous mass that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes.

questions.text: A 6 year old girl was taken by her parents with slowly progressive visual loss, followed by slight protuberance of eyeball in one eye. On examination, the following slit lamp picture was noted. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

The image shows multiple, small, orange-brown nodules on the iris. These nodules are known as Lisch nodules and are a classic, pathognomonic sign of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Lisch nodules are benign hamartomas of the iris.
The clinical presentation of a 6-year-old child with slowly progressive visual loss and a protruberance of the eyeball is also highly suggestive of NF1. This can be caused by an optic pathway glioma, which is a common tumor in children with NF1. The proptosis (protruberance of the eyeball) is due to the mass effect of the tumor within the orbit.

Incorrect Options
Tuberous Sclerosis: This genetic disorder is characterized by benign tumors in multiple organs. Ocular findings include retinal hamartomas (astrocytic hamartomas), not Lisch nodules.

Ataxia Telangiectasia: This is a rare, neurodegenerative disease that causes severe disability. Ocular findings are typically telangiectasias (spider veins) of the conjunctiva.

Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome: This is a rare, inherited disorder that causes tumors and cysts in many parts of the body. Ocular findings include retinal angiomas.

questions.text:
A previously normal newborn infant in a community hospital nursery is noted to be cyanotic at 14 hours of life. She is placed on a face mask with oxygen flowing at 10 L/min. She remains cyanotic, and her pulse oximetry reading does not change. An arterial blood gas shows her PaO2 to be 23 mm Hg. Bilateral breath sounds are present, and she has no murmur. She is breathing deeply and quickly, but she is not retracting. While you are waiting for the transport team from the nearby children's
hospital, you should initiate which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The vignette describes an infant with a ductal-dependent cyanotic congenital heart lesion. In this example, the child had pulmonary atresia without a corresponding VSD; another example would have been transposition of the great vessels without a septal defect to allow mixing of oxygenated and non-oxygenated blood. 

Cyanotic infants who do not improve then- saturations with supplemental oxygen should be evaluated carefully for structural heart disease. The ductus arteriosis typically closes in the first few hours of life; thus, these children will develop their cyanosis in the same time frame. 

Prostaglandin E1 will help keep the ductus patent until a surgical procedure can be performed. PGE1 does have the tendency to cause hypoventilation, so arrangements must be made for a potential artificial airway if necessary. Indomethacin closes a patent ductus arteriosis. Adenosine is used for supraventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the given CT scan.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

The coronal CT image shows a markedly dilated renal pelvis and calyces on the left side, a condition known as hydronephrosis. The obstruction is at the junction where the renal pelvis meets the ureter (the ureteropelvic junction, or PUJ), as the ureter distal to this point is not dilated. This is the classic radiographic sign of a PUJ obstruction. The right kidney appears normal.


The CT scan shows PUJ obstruction, which is a ureteropelvic junction obstruction.

The coronal CT image shows a markedly dilated renal pelvis and calyces on the left side, a condition known as hydronephrosis. The obstruction is at the junction where the renal pelvis meets the ureter (the ureteropelvic junction, or PUJ), as the ureter distal to this point is not dilated. This is the classic radiographic sign of a PUJ obstruction. The right kidney appears normal.

Incorrect Options
Renal cyst: A renal cyst would appear as a simple, well-defined, fluid-filled sac within the kidney parenchyma. It would not cause the widespread dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces.

Renal tumor: A renal tumor would appear as a solid or complex mass and would not cause this pattern of hydronephrosis unless it was large enough to compress the PUJ, which is not what the image suggests.

Multicystic kidney: This is a congenital condition where the kidney is replaced by multiple cysts, and there is no normal renal parenchyma. The kidney shown has a clear distinction between the dilated pelvis and the compressed parenchyma.

questions.text: Clinical features of 11-beta hydroxylase deficiency are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Although cortisol is not synthesized efficiently, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal, and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by the intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency such as hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Approximately 65% of patients become hypertensive, although this can take several years to develop. Hypertension is probably a consequence of elevated levels of deoxycorticosterone,, which has mineralocorticoid activity. Infants may transiently develop signs of mineralocorticoid deficiency after treatment with hydrocortisone is instituted. 

This is presumably from sudden suppression of deoxycorticosterone secretion in a patient with atrophy of the zona glomerulosa caused by chronic suppression of rennin activity. All signs and symptoms of androgen excess that are found in 21- hydroxylase deficiency may also occur in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency.

questions.text: A patient exhibits symptoms of repressing traumatic memories from childhood. Which part of Freud's model of the mind is responsible for this defense mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The unconscious mind in Freud’s model stores thoughts, memories, and desires that are unacceptable or traumatic, which the conscious mind cannot tolerate. Repression is a defense mechanism where the mind pushes distressing memories or impulses into the unconscious to reduce anxiety. Traumatic childhood memories are typically not accessible to conscious awareness, making the unconscious the key part responsible.

Incorrect Options:
A. Conscious mind:
The conscious mind contains thoughts and perceptions currently aware to the person. It is not responsible for repression, which occurs outside conscious awareness.

B. Preconscious mind:
The preconscious stores memories and knowledge that are not currently in awareness but can be recalled easily. It is not the primary site of repressed traumatic memories.

D. Superego:
The superego represents internalized moral standards and ideals, which can generate guilt or shame, but it is not the location of repressed memories itself.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with dyslipidemia is prescribed atorvastatin. Which of the following is a potential side effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atorvastatin, a HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, lowers cholesterol by inhibiting hepatic cholesterol synthesis. A well-known adverse effect is muscle toxicity, ranging from myalgia (muscle pain) to rare rhabdomyolysis. Patients may present with muscle weakness, tenderness, or elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels. Risk factors include high statin doses, advanced age, and concomitant medications.
Incorrect Options:
A. Hyperglycemia:
While statins can slightly increase blood glucose levels, hyperglycemia is not a primary or common side effect, and it is less clinically significant than muscle toxicity.
C. Flushing:
Flushing is a characteristic side effect of niacin, not statins.
D. Gallstones:
Gallstones are associated with fibrates, especially gemfibrozil, rather than atorvastatin.

choices.text: Infection at the site of injection
History of post Dural puncture headache

questions.text: All are contraindication to epidural block except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

History of post Dural puncture headache

A history of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is not a contraindication for performing an epidural block. While PDPH can be a complication of spinal anesthesia, it does not necessarily preclude a patient from having an epidural block in the future. The etiology of PDPH involves a dural puncture, which is not typically associated with epidural anesthesia as it involves placing a needle into the epidural space rather than puncturing the dura. In fact, for patients with a history of PDPH from spinal anesthesia, an epidural block may sometimes be preferred as it carries a lower risk of dural puncture.

Incorrect Options:

Option (A): Patient refusal
Patient refusal is a clear contraindication to any medical procedure, including epidural anesthesia. If a patient refuses to undergo the procedure, it is not ethically or legally permissible to proceed. Consent is a crucial component of patient care, and performing any intervention without consent can lead to legal consequences, as well as compromise patient trust and safety.

Option (B): Infection at the site of injection
Infection at the site of injection is an absolute contraindication to performing an epidural block. If there is an infection at or near the proposed injection site (such as a skin infection or abscess), the risk of introducing bacteria into the epidural space is significantly increased. This could result in serious complications, such as epidural abscess or meningitis, which can be life-threatening. Therefore, an infection at the site must be treated or resolved before proceeding with an epidural.

Option (C): INR > 1.5
An INR greater than 1.5 is a contraindication to epidural anesthesia because it indicates an increased risk of bleeding. If the INR is elevated, there is a higher likelihood of bleeding complications, such as epidural hematoma, which can compress the spinal cord and lead to permanent neurological damage. Therefore, it is critical to ensure that the INR is within a safe range (generally less than 1.5) before performing an epidural block.

questions.text: Schwartz operation is also called as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

(Cortical Mastoidectomy) because Schwartz operation is another name for cortical mastoidectomy, a surgical procedure used to drain infections from the mastoid air cells.

Schwartz operation (Cortical Mastoidectomy) is performed to treat mastoiditis, cholesteatoma, or chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) without cholesteatoma.

The posterior wall of the external auditory canal is preserved, differentiating it from more extensive mastoid surgeries.

The primary goal is removal of diseased mastoid air cells while maintaining ear structures.

Incorrect Options:

Option B (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy)
In modified radical mastoidectomy, the posterior wall of the external auditory canal is removed, creating a common cavity between the mastoid and middle ear.
This is done in cholesteatoma cases where disease clearance is necessary.

Option C (Radical Mastoidectomy)
In radical mastoidectomy, both the posterior canal wall and tympanic membrane are removed, leading to complete exteriorization of the mastoid and middle ear.
Used for extensive cholesteatoma and irreversible middle ear disease.

Option D (Fenestration Operation)
Fenestration operation was historically used for otosclerosis before the development of stapedectomy.
It involves creating a new opening in the lateral semicircular canal to improve hearing.
It is unrelated to mastoidectomy procedures.

questions.text: The best test for universal screening of metabolic disorders is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Blood tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) is the gold standard for universal newborn screening of inborn errors of metabolism (IEMs). It can simultaneously detect multiple metabolic disorders, including aminoacidopathies, organic acidemias, and fatty acid oxidation disorders, from a single dried blood spot. Its high sensitivity, specificity, and ability to screen for a large panel of disorders make it ideal for population-level universal screening.

Incorrect Options:
B. Blood HPLC:
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is useful for specific metabolic tests, like hemoglobinopathies or some aminoacidopathies, but it cannot screen multiple metabolic disorders simultaneously.

C. Urine GCMS:
Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GCMS) is used for targeted metabolic investigations, especially organic acidurias, but it is less practical for universal newborn screening.

D. Guthrie’s test:
The Guthrie bacterial inhibition assay was an early screening method for phenylketonuria (PKU) but is limited to a single disorder and has largely been replaced by TMS.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing preanesthetic evaluation. He is seated upright with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phomation. The image of the mouth is given below. Which class does he belong to according to the modified Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Class I In the given image, the faucial pillars, uvula, and the soft palate are all visible. Therefore, this patient is classified as class I according to the modified Mallampati score. The modified Mallampati score is used to assess the difficulty of endotracheal intubation in a patient. The patient is seated upright with the neutral position of the head, open mouth, and protruded tongue and the patient is asked to not speak. The classification is done based on the visibility of structures through the mouth in this position

questions.text: A hypermetropic patient with closed angles on gonioscopy has IOP of 25 mm Hg with normal optic disc with normal visual fields. Diagnosis and initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The patient shows anatomical closure of the anterior chamber angles, elevated IOP (>21 mmHg), but no optic nerve damage or visual field loss. This fits the diagnosis of primary angle closure (PAC). The first-line definitive treatment is laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI), which creates an alternate pathway for aqueous humor, relieving pupillary block and preventing progression to primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG). Early intervention reduces the risk of optic nerve damage.

Incorrect Options:
A. Primary angle closure suspect – observe:
This is reserved for patients with narrow angles but normal IOP. Here, IOP is already elevated, so observation is insufficient.

C. Primary angle closure – topical antiglaucoma:
Topical medications reduce IOP temporarily but do not address the underlying pupillary block, so they are not first-line definitive therapy.

D. Ocular hypertension – topical antiglaucoma:
Ocular hypertension is diagnosed when IOP is elevated with open angles. Here, the patient has angle closure, so this diagnosis is incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with low mood, anhedonia, and fatigue for the past 3 weeks. Which type of depression is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Melancholic depression is a subtype of major depressive disorder characterized by anhedonia (loss of pleasure), pervasive low mood, psychomotor changes, and early morning awakening. Symptoms are not dependent on environmental or situational factors and are considered endogenous. Fatigue, significant loss of interest, and lack of mood reactivity (the patient cannot feel better even with positive events) are hallmarks of melancholic depression, making this the most likely diagnosis.
Incorrect Options:
A. Atypical depression:
Characterized by mood reactivity, increased appetite, hypersomnia, and leaden paralysis. The patient here does not show these atypical features.
B. Premenstrual dysphoric disorder:
Occurs cyclically during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle and resolves after menstruation. The patient’s symptoms persist for 3 weeks, not just premenstrually.
D. Seasonal affective disorder:
Symptoms occur seasonally, typically during winter months, and remit in spring or summer. There is no mention of seasonal pattern here.

questions.text: Which cardiac defect has the worst prognosis, without immediate surgical correction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

d-Transposition of the great arteries is a medical emergency. Cyanosis and tachypnea are most often recognized within the 1st hours or days of life. If it is not treated, the vast majority of these infants would not survive the neonatal period. Hypoxemia is usually moderate to severe, depending on the degree of atrial level shunting and whether the ductus is partially open or totally closed. Infants who remain severely hypoxic or acidotic despite prostaglandin infusion should undergo Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy. 

A successful Rashkind atrial septostomy should result in a rise in PaO2 to 35-50 mm Hg and elimination of any pressure gradient across the atrial septum. Some patients with TGA and VSD may require balloon atrial septostomy because of poor mixing, even though the VSD is large. If the VSD associated with d-TGA is small, the clinical lit manifestations, laboratory findings, and treatment are similar to those described previously for transposition with an intact ventricular
septum.

When the VSD is large and not restrictive to ventricular ejection, significant mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood usually occurs and clinical manifestations of cardiac failure are seen. The degree of cyanosis may be subtle and sometimes may not be recognized until an oxygen saturation measurement is performed. 

The physiology of I- TGA is quite different from that of d-TGA. The double inversion of the atrioventricular and ventriculoarterial relationships result in desaturated right atrial blood appropriately flowing to the lungs and oxygenated pulmonary venous blood appropriately flowing to the aorta. The circulation is thus physiologically “corrected.” Without other defects, the
hemodynamics would be nearly normal.

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a child who presented with progressive breathlessness is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Tetralogy of Fallot The above image shows a boot-shaped heart which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). It shows an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy and a concave pulmonary arterial segment.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Osteochondroma is the most common benign bone tumor, often seen in adolescents and young adults.

It arises near the growth plate (metaphysis) and is characterized by a painless, palpable bony mass.

Radiographically, it appears as a bony projection away from the joint, often with a cartilage cap.

Most commonly occurs around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia).

Incorrect options:

A. Multiple myeloma: Usually affects older adults (>50 years), presents with bone pain, anemia, and lytic lesions, not a painless lump in an adolescent.

B. Chondroblastoma: Typically arises in the epiphysis of long bones, often painful, and occurs in teenagers.

D. Osteoid osteoma: Small, painful lesion (<1.5 cm), typically causes night pain relieved by NSAIDs, not a painless lump.

questions.text: Which of the following parameter is not obtained from cohort study
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A cohort study is a type of longitudinal study where a group of individuals (cohort) is followed over time to see who develops a particular outcome or disease. The main parameters obtained from cohort studies include:

Incidence: Cohort studies track new cases over time, so incidence (the number of new cases per population at risk over a specific time period) can be directly calculated.

Relative risk (RR): Since cohort studies compare exposed vs unexposed groups over time, RR can be calculated to measure the strength of association between exposure and outcome.

Attributable risk (AR): Cohort studies allow calculation of AR, which represents the portion of incidence in the exposed group that is due to the exposure.

Other options:

A. Incidence: Correctly obtained; measures new cases in cohort over time.

B. Relative risk: Correctly obtained; compares risk between exposed and unexposed groups.

C. Attributable risk: Correctly obtained; shows excess risk due to exposure.

questions.text:
A 9 day old neonate, born by vaginal delivery to a 21 yr old healthy woman, is presented with fever, lethargy, and poor feeding. There are no diagnostic findings on physical examination, and results of sepsis evaluation, including a CBC and cerebrospinal fluid studies, are unremarkable. Ampicillin and cefotaxime are begun. Two days later all bacterial cultures are negative but the child's clinical condition worsens, with falling blood pressure, decreased level of consciousness,
thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. The indicated change in treatment is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Infants with disseminated HSV infections generally become ill at 5-11 days of life. Their clinical picture is similar to that of infants with bacterial sepsis, consisting of hyperthermia or hypothermia., irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting. 

They may also exhibit respiratory distress, cyanosis, apneic spells, jaundice, purpuric rash, and evidence of central nervous system infection; seizures arc common.
