Skin vesicles are seen in about 75% of cases. If untreated, the infection causes shock and disseminated intravascular coagulation; approximately 90% of these infants die, and most survivors have severe neurologic sequelae.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with personality changes, abnormal movements, jaundice and pruritus. MRI of the brain was taken and is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Wilson's disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is a rare genetic disorder caused by a buildup of copper in the body. It primarily affects the liver and the central nervous system. The patient's symptoms align with this diagnosis:

Personality changes and abnormal movements: These are neurological symptoms resulting from copper accumulation in the basal ganglia, a group of structures deep within the brain involved in motor control.

Jaundice and pruritus: These are classic signs of liver disease, which is the other major organ system affected.

MRI findings: The T2-weighted MRI image shows bilateral, symmetric hyperintensities in the basal ganglia, specifically in the putamen and globus pallidus, and in the midbrain, particularly in the tectum and red nuclei. These findings are often referred to as the "face of the giant panda" sign due to their appearance in axial T2-weighted MRI images, which is considered a classic, though not exclusive, finding in Wilson's disease.

Other Options
Huntington's disease: This is a genetic neurodegenerative disorder characterized by a different pattern of atrophy, particularly of the caudate nucleus, and is not typically associated with liver disease.

Hemochromatosis: This is a genetic disorder of iron overload, which can also affect the liver and other organs but presents with different neurological and MRI findings.

Sarcoidosis: This is an inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the brain, but it typically presents with granulomas and a different MRI pattern.

choices.text: Horizontal line from right eye and dot in center
Vertical line from right eye and dot in center
Horizontal line from left eye and dot in center
Vertical line from left eye and dot in center

questions.text: If this patient is orthotropia, what will he see
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•  Maddox Rod: The test uses a maddox rod, which is a lens with parallel cylindrical grooves, to dissociate the two eyes. When looking at a white light source, the maddox rod in front of one eye causes the light to be perceived as a bright, colored line. The line's orientation is perpendicular to the cylindrical grooves.

•  Test Setup: The maddox rod is typically placed in front of one eye, and the patient focuses on a distant or near light source.

•  Orthotropia (Perfect Eye Alignment): An orthotropic patient is one whose eyes are perfectly aligned, meaning there is no latent or manifest strabismus (eye misalignment).

•  Patient's Perspective: In the image, the maddox rod is held with its grooves in a vertical orientation in front of the right eye. This causes the right eye to see a horizontal red line. The left eye, which is looking directly at the light source, sees a white dot. Since the patient is orthotropic, their eyes are aligned, and they will see the horizontal line pass directly through the central white dot. Therefore, the patient will see a horizontal line from the right eye and a dot in the center, which are superimposed.

questions.text: All are signs of successful stellate ganglion block except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mydriasis

Mydriasis (dilation of the pupil) is not a typical sign of a successful stellate ganglion block. A stellate ganglion block is performed to block sympathetic nerves and is generally expected to result in a series of signs associated with sympathetic blockade, particularly on the ipsilateral side of the body. However, mydriasis is not one of these signs. In fact, the blockage of the sympathetic fibers should result in miosis (constriction of the pupil) due to the unopposed parasympathetic activity. Mydriasis, or pupil dilation, can occur due to other factors such as certain medications or neural damage but is not an expected effect of a stellate ganglion block.

Incorrect Options:

Option (A): Ptosis
Ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) is a common sign of a successful stellate ganglion block. The sympathetic fibers that are blocked by the stellate ganglion block supply the muscles that elevate the eyelid (the levator palpebrae muscle). Therefore, the loss of sympathetic input can cause ptosis, which is often used as an indicator of successful blockade.

Option (C): Guttmann’s sign
Guttmann’s sign refers to the warmness and redness of the skin over the affected side of the face following a stellate ganglion block. It is a characteristic sign that indicates successful blockade of the sympathetic nerves. This is because sympathetic blockade leads to vasodilation, which causes the skin to become warm and flushed.

Option (D): Decreased sweating over the face
Decreased sweating over the face is another typical sign of a successful stellate ganglion block. The sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands in the face are blocked, resulting in reduced sweating on the affected side. This is considered one of the hallmark signs of a successful block, along with the other signs such as ptosis and Guttmann's sign.

questions.text: Identify the intraocular lens?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

An anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is an artificial lens designed to be implanted in the front part of the eye, in the space between the iris and the cornea. ACIOLs are typically rigid, single-piece lenses with distinctive haptics (the arms that hold the lens in place). These haptics are designed to rest in the angle of the anterior chamber, which provides support and fixation for the lens. ACIOLs are often used when the posterior capsule, which normally supports a posterior chamber IOL, is damaged or absent.
• Query successful
The image displays an intraocular lens (IOL) with large, rigid haptics designed to be placed in the anterior chamber of the eye. Therefore, the correct answer is B. Anterior chamber.
Explanation
An anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is an artificial lens designed to be implanted in the front part of the eye, in the space between the iris and the cornea. ACIOLs are typically rigid, single-piece lenses with distinctive haptics (the arms that hold the lens in place). These haptics are designed to rest in the angle of the anterior chamber, which provides support and fixation for the lens. ACIOLs are often used when the posterior capsule, which normally supports a posterior chamber IOL, is damaged or absent.
Other Options
• A. Posterior chamber: Posterior chamber IOLs (PCIOLs) are the most common type of IOL used in cataract surgery today. They are placed behind the iris, within the capsular bag, and typically have a different, less rigid haptic design.
• C. Toric: Toric IOLs are a type of lens designed to correct astigmatism. The distinguishing feature of a toric lens is not its shape, but rather the presence of alignment markers on the optic to ensure proper orientation to correct the astigmatism. They can be either anterior or posterior chamber lenses.
• D. Scleral fixated: Scleral-fixated IOLs are a type of posterior chamber lens that is sutured directly to the sclera of the eye. This method is used when there is insufficient capsular support for a standard PCIOL and when an ACIOL is not a good option. While they have haptics, they are designed differently to accommodate sutures, rather than the broad, prominent haptics seen in the image.

questions.text: A 37 year-old male motorcyclist presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident with significant left hip pain and inability to bear weight. The affected leg is in the position as shown in the below image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

In this case, the patient’s affected leg is seen in external rotation, abduction, and slight flexion. This leg position is characteristic of anterior dislocation of the hip, which occurs when the femoral head dislocates anteriorly out of the acetabulum. The X-ray (image B) also shows the femoral head displaced anteriorly and inferiorly to the acetabulum. Clinically, patients present with inability to bear weight, pain, and abnormal limb positioning after trauma, such as a road traffic accident.

Incorrect Options:

A. Posterior dislocation of hip – The most common type of hip dislocation. The limb would be in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation, not external rotation as seen here.

B. Central dislocation of hip – Involves fracture of the acetabular wall with femoral head pushed into the pelvis. X-ray would show the femoral head intruding medially into the pelvic cavity, which is not seen in this case.

C. Fracture shaft of femur – Presents with swelling, deformity, abnormal mobility, and crepitus along the shaft. The hip joint dislocation pattern (external rotation with abduction) and the X-ray exclude this diagnosis.

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Pancoast tumor MRI is useful in Pancoast tumor because of the associated soft tissue infiltration, extent of which can be best visualised using an MRI

Incorrect responses:

A. Small cell lung carcinoma: Usually centrally located and diagnosed primarily with CT thorax and bronchoscopy. MRI is not routinely required.

B. Adenocarcinoma: Typically peripheral; CECT thorax is adequate for diagnosis, staging, and surgical planning. MRI is not standard.

C. Carcinoid tumors: Can be diagnosed and staged with CT and bronchoscopy; MRI is reserved for rare cases of mediastinal invasion.

questions.text: What is the cut-off score on the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) that indicates dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The MMSE is a widely used cognitive screening tool assessing orientation, registration, attention, calculation, recall, language, and visuospatial skills. A score below 24 out of 30 is generally considered indicative of cognitive impairment or dementia. It is a screening tool, not a definitive diagnosis, and scores should be interpreted in context of age, education, and clinical evaluation.
Incorrect Options:
A. Less than 18 out of 30:
A score this low indicates moderate to severe cognitive impairment, not the general cut-off for dementia screening.
B. Less than 21 out of 30:
This is too restrictive; many patients with mild dementia score above 21.
D. Less than 27 out of 30:
This cut-off is sometimes used for highly educated individuals to detect subtle impairment, but the standard universal cut-off is <24.

choices.text: Continue the original pattern of CPR
Increase the depth of sternal depression

questions.text: A 68-year-old man collapses in the middle of a mall. A good Samaritan immediately rushes to help the victim. He assesses the responsiveness and pulse and immediately starts cardiopulmonary resuscitation and calls for help by dialling 911. During cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) he performs external chest compression at the rate of 90/min with 2 inches of sternal depression. The most appropriate action is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increase the rate of compression

The rate of chest compressions during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) should be between 100 and 120 compressions per minute according to the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines. In this scenario, the rescuer is performing chest compressions at 90/min, which is below the recommended rate. Increasing the rate to within the recommended range (100–120/min) improves the chances of maintaining adequate blood flow to vital organs during CPR.

Incorrect Options:

A. Continue the original pattern of CPR
This is incorrect because the current compression rate of 90/min is too slow. Adequate circulation during CPR depends on maintaining the recommended compression rate. Sticking to 90/min may result in inadequate perfusion to the brain and heart.

B. Increase the duration of compression
This is incorrect because the duration of chest compressions is not a focus in CPR. Instead, the emphasis is on achieving the correct rate (100–120/min) and depth (at least 2 inches) of compressions. Increasing the duration of each compression may interfere with maintaining the appropriate compression rate.

D. Increase the depth of sternal depression
This is incorrect because the rescuer is already achieving the appropriate depth of 2 inches for chest compressions. Increasing the depth beyond the recommended range could cause injury to the patient, such as rib fractures or damage to internal organs.

questions.text: Given below is an instrument used for irrigation. In which of the following procedures will it not be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Trephination

The instrument is Rose’s sinus douching cannula. It is used in irrigation of the maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell Luc operation. The direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside.

Rose's sinus douching cannula is a medical instrument primarily used for irrigation or cleansing of the sinuses during certain procedures. It is used to irrigate the sinus cavities, ensuring that they are cleared of debris or infected material.

Let’s break down the options:

A. Intranasal antrostomy:
In intranasal antrostomy, a surgical procedure is performed to create an opening between the maxillary sinus and the nasal cavity, usually to allow for drainage or to treat chronic sinusitis. Rose’s sinus douching cannula is often used for irrigation after such procedures to help cleanse the sinus and ensure proper drainage. Therefore, the cannula would be used in this procedure.

B. Caldwell-Luc operation:
The Caldwell-Luc operation is a procedure used to access the maxillary sinus through the maxillary bone to treat conditions like chronic sinusitis, remove polyps, or drain abscesses. Rose's sinus douching cannula is often used in post-operative care to irrigate the sinus, ensuring that it is clear of any residual material. Hence, the cannula would also be used in this procedure.

C. Trephination:
Trephination refers to a procedure where a hole is made in the skull or a sinus to relieve pressure, often for conditions like abscesses, or to allow drainage. However, this procedure does not typically involve irrigation through a cannula like Rose's sinus douching cannula, especially if the procedure is focused on draining a fluid collection. Therefore, the cannula would not be used in this procedure.

questions.text: A young male comes to your office with sudden painless loss of vision in one eye preceded by floaters. He has previous episodes of same in past. Vision was Hand movements and there was no view of retina by indirect ophthalmoscopy. What should be the investigation in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

When the fundus is not visible due to media opacities (e.g., vitreous hemorrhage) and there is suspicion of retinal detachment or vitreoretinal pathology, a B-scan ultrasonography is the investigation of choice. It provides a real-time cross-sectional image of the posterior segment, allowing visualization of the retina, vitreous, and optic nerve, even when the view is blocked. It is non-invasive and highly sensitive for detecting retinal tears, detachments, or vitreous hemorrhage.

Incorrect Options:
A. Optical coherence tomography (OCT):
OCT is useful for macular or retinal layer imaging, but it requires a clear optical media and cannot image the retina if the fundus is not visible.

C. Ultrasound A scan:
A-scan measures axial length of the eye and is primarily used for biometry before cataract surgery, not for structural assessment of the retina or vitreous.

D. Fluorescein angiography:
This requires a visible fundus and is used to evaluate retinal vascular pathology, so it is not suitable when the retina cannot be visualized.

questions.text: A 24-year-old adult presents to the ER after a high velocity road traffic accident with tachypnea, petechial haemorrhages in the palpebral conjunctiva and lung crepitations. His femur radiograph is as below. The best treatment option is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

External fixation External fixation is the best treatment option in the given case. The radiograph shows a femur shaft fracture, and with the additional information in the question, the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome should be borne in mind. In keeping with the principles of damage control orthopedics, the fracture is initially stabilized by external fixation to prevent further progression of fat embolism. Definitive treatment plans are considered later.

questions.text: A 3 yrs old girl presents to your office with acute onset of lethargy and pallor. The child's mother reports that the child had bloody diarrhea for 5 days that cleared 1 day before presenting to your office. She also notes acute onset of cola-colored urine. On examination, the patient is pale and lethargic. Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Response (D)

This patient presents with a classic history of post-diarrheal hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which typically follows infection with Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC). HUS is characterized by the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. The first step in diagnosis is a complete blood cell count (CBC) to evaluate for:
• Anemia (due to hemolysis)

• Thrombocytopenia (low platelets)

These findings are critical to confirm HUS and guide further management.

Incorrect Options:
A. Urinalysis:
Urinalysis may show hematuria and proteinuria, but it is not the first diagnostic test for HUS; CBC is more critical for identifying the hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia.

B. X-ray examination of the abdomen:
Abdominal X-ray is not useful in diagnosing HUS; it may be considered if there is suspicion of intestinal complications, but it does not provide hematological information.

C. Urine culture:
Urine culture is used to identify urinary tract infections, but HUS is post-diarrheal and primarily hematological, so urine culture is not indicated initially.

questions.text: A young baby with hypotonia and development delay is referred to ophthalmology. The intra-ocular pressure is 29mmHg. The following slit lamp finding was observed. What would be most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Lowe syndrome
Lowe syndrome, also known as oculocerebrorenal syndrome, is a rare X-linked recessive genetic disorder. It is caused by a mutation in the OCRL gene, which affects the function of a protein called inositol polyphosphate-5-phosphatase. The clinical triad of Lowe syndrome includes:
1. Ocular abnormalities: Congenital cataracts are almost always present at birth or shortly after. Glaucoma, characterized by high intraocular pressure, is also a very common feature. The image provided, showing a congenital cataract, aligns with this.
2. Neurological abnormalities: This includes intellectual disability and, as seen in the question, developmental delay and hypotonia (low muscle tone).
3. Renal (kidney) abnormalities: The patient develops renal tubular dysfunction, leading to a condition similar to Fanconi syndrome.
The combination of hypotonia, developmental delay, glaucoma, and congenital cataracts presented in the question strongly points to Lowe syndrome.

Other Options
•  A. Alport syndrome: Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting collagen in the kidneys, ears, and eyes. While it can cause ocular abnormalities like anterior lenticonus, which is a cone-shaped lens, it does not typically present with the hypotonia and developmental delay seen in this case. The key features are progressive hearing loss and kidney disease.
•  C. Galactosemia: Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to process galactose. It can cause cataracts, but these are typically described as "oil droplet" cataracts and are often reversible if a galactose-free diet is initiated early. It does not present with the hallmark neurological and renal features of Lowe syndrome.
•  D. Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV): This is a congenital developmental anomaly of the eye caused by the failure of the primary vitreous to regress. It is usually unilateral and presents with leukocoria (a white pupillary reflex) and a small, underdeveloped eye (microphthalmia). It is a localized ocular disorder and does not cause systemic features like hypotonia and developmental delay.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia exhibits emotional expressions that are inappropriate for the situation and do not match their internal mood. This is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Incongruent affect occurs when a person’s external emotional expression does not correspond to their internal feelings. In schizophrenia, this is commonly observed, such as laughing in a sad situation or showing anger in a neutral context. It reflects disorganization of emotional processing and is considered a negative symptom of schizophrenia.

Incorrect Options:
A. Congruent affect:
Congruent affect occurs when a person’s emotional expression matches their internal mood (e.g., appearing sad when feeling sad). This is normal and appropriate.

C. Flat affect:
Flat affect refers to minimal or absent emotional expression, regardless of internal mood. The patient may feel emotions internally but shows very little outward expression.

D. Labile affect:
Labile affect is characterized by rapid, exaggerated changes in emotion, often shifting inappropriately or abruptly, but it does not necessarily mismatch the internal mood.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 1 in the picture
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The image shows a cross-section of the upper eyelid, and the structure marked as "1" is the Orbicularis muscle.
• Orbicularis Oculi Muscle (marked as 1): This muscle is a sphincter that surrounds the eye, forming concentric rings. It is responsible for closing the eyelids, a function known as palpebral fasciculation. Its location is superficial, lying directly beneath the skin of the eyelid. In the diagram, structure 1 is shown as a large, concentric muscle mass that is continuous around the eye, which is the characteristic anatomy of the orbicularis oculi.
Other Options 
• A. Levator muscle: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle (marked as 4) is the primary muscle responsible for elevating the upper eyelid. It is located deep within the eyelid, above the other structures.
• C. Tarsus: The tarsus (marked as 3) is a dense connective tissue plate that provides structural support and shape to the eyelid. It is located just deep to the orbicularis muscle.
• D. Muller muscle: The Muller muscle, or superior tarsal muscle (marked as 2), is a small, smooth muscle that helps to maintain the elevated position of the eyelid. It is located deep to the levator muscle and inserts onto the tarsus.

questions.text: IVIG-resistant Kawasaki Disease occurs in approximately …….of patients and is defined by persistent or recrudescent fever 36 hr after completion of the initial IVIG infusion.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

IVIG-resistant Kawasaki Disease occurs in approximately 15% of patients and is defined by persistent or recrudescent fever 36 hr after completion of the initial IVIG infusion. Patients with IVIG resistance are at increased risk for CAA> Typically, another dose of IVIG at 2 g/kg is administered to patients with IVIG resistance.

choices.text: Woodruff’s plexus appear  to  originate  from posterior  pharyngeal  wall  and  arterial  in origin
In young persons venous bleeding is more common
Posterior epistaxis usually occur after 40 yrs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding epistaxis is untrue:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Woodruff’s plexus appears to originate from the posterior pharyngeal wall and is arterial in origin (Untrue Statement).

Woodruff’s plexus is a network of veins located in the posterior part of the lateral nasal wall, and it is primarily venous in origin, not arterial. The incorrect part of the statement is the claim that it originates from the posterior pharyngeal wall and is arterial. Unlike Kiesselbach’s plexus, which is the main site for anterior epistaxis and is supplied by branches of the external and internal carotid arteries, Woodruff’s plexus is primarily involved in posterior epistaxis, which is often venous in nature.

Incorrect Options:

A. Anterior epistaxis is more common 
Anterior epistaxis accounts for 90% of nosebleeds, commonly originating from Little’s area (Kiesselbach’s plexus). It is usually mild, self-limiting, and more common in children and young adults due to trauma (e.g., nose-picking) or dry air.

C. In young persons, venous bleeding is more common 
In young individuals, epistaxis often results from minor trauma or mucosal irritation, leading to venous oozing rather than brisk arterial bleeding. Since the anterior nasal mucosa is highly vascularized, small venous bleeds are common in this age group.

D. Posterior epistaxis usually occurs after 40 years 
Posterior epistaxis is more common in older adults (typically above 40 years) and is often associated with hypertension, atherosclerosis, or coagulopathies. It is usually more severe than anterior epistaxis and originates from branches of the sphenopalatine artery, requiring more intensive management, including posterior nasal packing or arterial embolization

questions.text: An otherwise, healthy, asymptomatic 16-yr-old African-American girl is found to have hypertension and 3+ proteinuria by dipstick testing on mid-day and 1st morning voided urine samples. The microscopic analysis shows 0-2 red blood cells per high-power field. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic-range proteinuria in African-American adolescents and adults. Key features include:
• Proteinuria (often nephrotic range)
• Minimal hematuria (0–2 RBCs/HPF)
• Hypertension (common in older children/adolescents)
• Usually asymptomatic otherwise

FSGS can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary, but in this demographic, idiopathic FSGS is more common. Persistent proteinuria on repeated urine tests and absence of systemic symptoms support this diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:
A. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis:
Typically presents with hematuria (cola-colored urine), edema, hypertension, and recent infection. Proteinuria is usually not nephrotic-range.

B. Diabetic nephropathy:
Unlikely in a healthy 16-year-old without diabetes; also, hypertension and proteinuria develop years after diabetes onset.

C. Minimal change nephrotic syndrome (MCNS):
MCNS usually presents with abrupt onset edema, massive proteinuria, and normal blood pressure. It is most common in younger children (2–6 years old).

questions.text: From what distance can a patient with visual acuity 6/60 can see the 6/60 letter on Snellen chart:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

6m
Visual acuity is expressed as a fraction, with the numerator representing the testing distance and the denominator representing the distance at which a normal eye can read the same line. For 6/60 vision, the patient can see at 6 meters what a person with normal vision can see at 60 meters. Thus, the patient can correctly identify the 6/60 letter only from 6 meters.
Incorrect Options:
A. 60 m:
This would be true for a person with 6/6 vision, not 6/60.
B. 36 m:
Incorrect; the patient sees only 1/10 of the normal distance, so 36 m is too far.
C. 24 m:
Incorrect; same reasoning as above — the patient cannot resolve the 6/60 letter at this distance.

questions.text: Indication of using these spectacles are all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The spectacles shown in the image are bifocal glasses, and the indication for their use is all of the given options except for D. Astigmatism.
Explanation
Bifocal glasses contain two different lens powers in a single lens: a top segment for viewing distant objects and a bottom segment for viewing close-up objects. These lenses are designed to correct conditions where both near and far vision are impaired.

• A. Presbyopia: This is the most common indication for bifocals. Presbyopia is the age-related loss of the eye's ability to focus on close objects, which bifocals are specifically designed to correct.

• B. Pediatric pseudophakia: This refers to a child who has had a cataract removed and replaced with an artificial intraocular lens (IOL). Since the eye's natural lens, which provides accommodation (the ability to change focus), has been removed, a bifocal is necessary to provide the child with a clear focus for near vision tasks like reading and writing.

• C. Accommodative esotropia: This is a type of eye misalignment where the eyes turn inward (esotropia) due to excessive accommodative effort. Bifocals can reduce this effort by providing a separate lens power for near work, thereby helping to control the inward eye turn.

Other Options 

• D. Astigmatism: Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by an uneven curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light to focus on multiple points instead of a single one on the retina. It is corrected with a cylindrical lens that counteracts the uneven curvature, not a bifocal lens. A patient with astigmatism may also need bifocals to correct presbyopia, but the bifocal itself does not correct the astigmatism.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical feature of Meniere’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulsatile tinnitus.

Meniere’s disease is a disorder of the inner ear caused by endolymphatic hydrops (excessive accumulation of endolymph in the cochlea and vestibular system). The tinnitus associated with Meniere’s disease is typically low-pitched, roaring, or buzzing, and non-pulsatile. Pulsatile tinnitus, on the other hand, is often associated with vascular disorders (e.g., arteriovenous malformations, carotid artery stenosis, or glomus tumors) and is not a characteristic feature of Meniere’s disease.

Incorrect Options:

A. Sensorineural Deafness 
Meniere’s disease leads to progressive sensorineural hearing loss due to damage to the cochlea. Initially, hearing loss is fluctuating and affects low frequencies, but as the disease progresses, it may become permanent and involve all frequencies.

B. Vertigo 
Episodic vertigo is a hallmark of Meniere’s disease. The vertigo episodes are spontaneous, last from 20 minutes to several hours, and are often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The episodes are due to excessive endolymph affecting the vestibular system.

D. Fluctuating Deafness 
Hearing loss in Meniere’s disease is fluctuating, meaning it can worsen and improve over time, especially in the early stages. This fluctuation is a key distinguishing feature from other causes of sensorineural hearing loss, such as presbycusis or noise-induced hearing loss, which are typically progressive and non-fluctuating.

questions.text: According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which organ is associated with the anal stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Response (B):

The anal stage occurs roughly between 18 months and 3 years of age. During this stage, the anus and bowel control are the primary focus of libidinal energy. Children derive pleasure from retaining or expelling feces, and experiences during this stage can influence personality traits such as orderliness, stubbornness, or control issues in adulthood.

Incorrect Options:
A. Mouth:
Associated with the oral stage (birth to 18 months), where pleasure centers on sucking, biting, and chewing.

C. Genitals:
Associated with the phallic stage (3–6 years), focusing on the genital organs and Oedipal/Electra complexes.

D. Breasts:
Although related to feeding, breasts are part of the oral stage, not the anal stage

choices.text: Topical steroids are safe and effective in interstitial keratitis
Oral Acyclovir 400 BD given after resolution of ocular infection decreased rate of recurrence
Salmon patch is seen in disciform keratitis
Topical steroids are not given in epithelial keratitis

questions.text: Which is false statement for Ocular Herpes simplex management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The statement is false because a “salmon patch” refers to the stromal keratitis seen in interstitial keratitis, not disciform keratitis. Disciform keratitis presents as a disc-shaped stromal edema with underlying endothelial involvement, often associated with keratic precipitates, but not a salmon-colored patch.

Incorrect Options 
A. Topical steroids are safe and effective in interstitial keratitis:
True. Topical corticosteroids reduce stromal inflammation in interstitial keratitis but should be used under supervision to avoid worsening epithelial disease.
B. Oral Acyclovir 400 mg BD after resolution:
True. Prophylactic oral acyclovir decreases recurrence rates in patients with recurrent ocular herpes.
D. Topical steroids are not given in epithelial keratitis:
True. Steroids delay healing and worsen viral replication in epithelial herpes simplex keratitis, so they are contraindicated until the epithelium has healed.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling in the forearm. On examination, there is a restriction of rotational movements of the arm. He informs getting injured while defending getting beaten by stick. Which of the following fractures is he most likely to have sustained?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The clinical scenario provides a classic history and mechanism for a Nightstick fracture:

Mechanism of Injury: The patient was injured while "defending getting beaten by a stick" (a defensive injury).

Fracture Type: This defensive posture involves raising the forearm to protect the head, resulting in a direct blow to the ulnar side of the forearm.

Resulting Injury: This direct, isolated trauma typically causes a transverse fracture of the ulnar shaft (the ulna is the bone that forms the point of the elbow and runs along the little finger side of the forearm).

The provided X-ray image shows an isolated fracture of the mid-shaft of the ulna with no apparent displacement of the radial head or wrist joint, confirming the diagnosis of a Nightstick fracture.

Incorrect Options
A. Greenstick fracture: This is an incomplete fracture where one side of the bone is broken and the other is bent. It occurs most often in children whose bones are softer, not in adults sustaining a direct, high-force blow.

C. Galeazzi fracture: This is a fracture of the distal third of the radius associated with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ) at the wrist. It involves the radius, not just an isolated ulnar shaft fracture.

D. Monteggia fracture: This is a fracture of the proximal ulna (upper shaft) associated with dislocation of the radial head at the elbow. It involves a severe injury to both bones (or a joint dislocation), which is not an isolated ulnar shaft fracture.

questions.text: All of the following are part of the classical triad of the condition shown in the image attached except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation
Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital skeletal anomaly that results from a failure of segmentation of the cervical somites, leading to the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae. The cardinal features of this condition, often referred to as the classical triad, are:
• Short webbed neck: This is a key external sign resulting from the shortened cervical spine.
• Low posterior hairline: This is a consequence of the shortened neck and is a defining feature.
• Decreased movements at neck: The fusion of the vertebrae severely restricts the neck's range of motion.
Other Options
• A. Short webbed neck, C. Decreased movements at neck, and D. Low posterior hairline:
These are the three defining features of the classical triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome. They are all correct features of the condition and are therefore not the answer to the question, which asks for the exception.
• B. Short stature:
While some patients with Klippel-Feil syndrome may also have short stature, it is not considered a part of the classical triad. The syndrome's hallmark features are specifically related to the fusion of the cervical vertebrae.

questions.text: Identify the sign and retinal layer in which its seen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation
• Hard Exudates: The yellowish, waxy-looking deposits scattered across the retina in the image are hard exudates. They are lipid- and protein-rich deposits that leak from damaged retinal capillaries due to chronic edema. They are a sign of diabetic macular edema and are also seen in other conditions like hypertensive retinopathy.
• Outer Plexiform Layer: Hard exudates are characteristically found in the outer plexiform layer of the retina. This is because this layer contains the nerve endings of the photoreceptors, which create a basket-like structure (Henle's layer) that traps the fluid and deposits, leading to their classic appearance.

Other options:
Soft Exudates: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, appear as fluffy, white patches with indistinct borders. They are not waxy like the deposits in the image. They are caused by ischemic infarction of the nerve fiber layer.
Nerve Fiber Layer: Soft exudates (cotton wool spots) are located in the nerve fiber layer, while hard exudates are in the outer plexiform layer.
Star-shaped deposits: The "star" shape seen in the image, also a collection of hard exudates, is a classic sign of severe macular edema. This star shape occurs because the fluid and exudates are trapped and spread within the basket-like structure of Henle's layer in the outer plexiform layer.

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete came to the orthopedic department with acute onset of pain in the lateral part of the foot while his routine practice. His radiograph of the foot is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Jones fracture The above radiograph shows a transverse fracture on the base of the 5th metatarsal at the metaphyseal- diaphyseal junction and the most likely diagnosis is Jones fracture. A strong abduction force to the forefoot causes a bending moment in the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction and results in Jones fracture. This type of injury occurs in a sudden change in direction by an athlete.

questions.text: A 9 days old full-term infant is admitted to the hospital with lethargy, fever, and increasing jaundice. Physical examination also reveals hepatomegaly. Laboratory results reveal a blood glucose  value of 10 mg/dL. total and direct bilirubin values of 15 and 7 mg/dL., respectively, and liver enzymes AST, 700 units/L, and ALT, 650 units/L. The next day the blood culture is positive for a gramnegative rod. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The diagnosis of uridyl transferase deficiency (galactosemia) should be considered in newborn or young infants with any of the following features: jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, hypoglycemia, seizures, lethargy, irritability, feeding difficulties, poor weight gain or failure to regain birth weight, aminoaciduria„ nuclear cataracts, vitreous hemorrhage, hepatic failure, liver cirrhosis, ascites, splenomegaly, or mental retardation. Patients with galactosemia, are at increased risk for Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis; the onset of sepsis often precedes the diagnosis of galactosemia.

questions.text: What is the principle behind ultrasound imaging?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ultrasound imaging is based on the piezoelectric effect, where certain crystals (e.g., quartz or lead zirconate titanate) generate electrical signals when mechanically deformed and vibrate to produce sound waves when an electrical signal is applied. The transducer emits high-frequency sound waves, which reflect off tissues and return to the transducer. These echoes are then converted into images, allowing visualization of internal structures.
Incorrect Options:
B. Doppler effect:
The Doppler effect is used in ultrasound to measure blood flow velocity, not for generating the imaging waves themselves.
C. Electromagnetic induction:
This principle underlies generators and transformers, not ultrasound imaging.
D. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR):
NMR is the basis of MRI, not ultrasound, and involves nuclear spin alignment in a magnetic field rather than sound wave propagation.

questions.text: A patient with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is likely to exhibit which of the following radiological signs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The bare orbit sign is characteristic of NF1, often due to sphenoid wing dysplasia. Radiographically, it appears as a defect or absence of the sphenoid bone, leading to herniation of orbital contents. This finding is significant in patients with NF1, especially those with pulsatile exophthalmos or orbital masses.

Incorrect Options:

B. Beheaded Scotty dog appearance:
This is seen in spondylolysis on oblique lumbar spine X-rays, unrelated to NF1.

C. Blade of grass sign:
Associated with Paget’s disease of bone, reflecting the typical lytic and sclerotic changes, not NF1.

D. Bone within bone appearance:
Seen in thalassemia, osteopetrosis, or chronic anemia, representing endocrine or marrow-related changes, unrelated to NF1.

questions.text:
A 6 month old infant began to vomit and ceased to gain weight. At 9 months he was again readmitted in the hospital. Routine examination and lab tests were normal, but after one week he came drowsy, his temperature rose to 39 degree C, and had hepatomegaly. Since the child could not take milk, even by tube feeds, intravenous glucose was given, and he improved his sensorium. 
Urine analysis showed very high glutamine and uracil.
What is the enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder and is X-linked. OTC catalyzes the reaction between carbamoyl phosphate and ornithine to form citrulline. Its deficiency leads to:
• Hyperammonemia, causing vomiting, lethargy, and altered sensorium
• Excess carbamoyl phosphate diverted to the pyrimidine pathway, resulting in orotic acid/uraciluria
• Elevated plasma glutamine as ammonia is detoxified
• Clinical improvement with intravenous glucose, which reduces catabolism and ammonia production
Incorrect Options:
A. Arginase:
Causes hyperargininemia, typically presenting later in childhood with spasticity and growth retardation, not acute neonatal/infant hyperammonemia.
B. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-1 (CPS1):
Also causes hyperammonemia, but uracil/orotic acid is not elevated, because carbamoyl phosphate cannot enter the pyrimidine pathway.
C. Glutaminase:
Very rare; deficiency affects glutamine metabolism, not associated with hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria.
